editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Amorous Bigotte: WITH THE SECOND PART OF Tegue O Divelly. A COMEDY, Acted by Their Majesty's Servants.
Written by THO. SHADWELL, Poet Laureat, and Historiographer Royal to Their MAJESTIES.
LONDON: Printed for Iames Knapton, at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-yard, 1690.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE CHARLES E. of Shrewsbury, &c.
div.p: I Have ever been ready to own all Obligations receiv'd from any Man; but being favour'd by so great and good a Man as your Lordship, I think it so much to my honour, that I cannot but be proud of it, which makes me take the first occasion to publish my Gratitude, and boast of your Patronage. Nor have I any other end in making bold with your Lordships Name before this Trifle. I would not be so unreasonable to desire your Lordship to defend the weakness of my Writings: I have been by long sickness made very unfit for that Task. A man ought not to hope to Please the world very much, who is not at ease, and somewhat pleas'd himself: Tho I have no reason to complain of the reception of this Play.

For my own, but much more for my Countrys sake, I rejoyce that there is a TALBOT still left to sustain the Honour of that Illustrious Family; so able, so sincere, and so disinterested a Minister; so real a Lover and Honourer of his King, equally faithful in his Services to him, and true to the Interest of his Country. (Nor can any one be faithful to the first, who is not true to the latter); for in effect they are but one; and they can never be odious enough who endeavour to divide it.

We still have a Talbot who is a firm Friend to the English, and a just Enemy to the French; and I doubt not, my Lord, but you will live by your Counsels and Actions to become as terrible to them as any of your brave Ancestors have been. I dare not be too forward in your just Commendations, Praise being not the end that a man who is truly great ever aims at; nor does an ingenuous Man delight in it: To such the conscience of doing well is the only satisfaction. But one thing out of the abundance of my heart I cannot restrain my self from observing in your Lordship.

The most important business of this world, the Education of Youth (which ought to be put into the hands of the ablest, wisest, most learn'd and vertuous men, who have no other interest but the bettering of mens minds; and because of the great trouble of the Office, it ought to have great Rewards and Dignities affix'd to it by the publick) is for want of those encouragements put upon such mean, weak, or corrupt persons, that it is the greatest task of a mans life to break loose from his Education, and shake off the prejudices he contracted by it; which none but a great Genius ever does▪ The rest, tho of the highest rank, swallow every
thing unchew'd, and take every thing unexamind from their first Dry-Nurses in Petticoats to their last in Square-Caps: Women begin with them, and young Priests end with 'em, who are sure to bring 'em up to the interest of the Clergy, tho it be never so much against that of the Laity.

Your Lordship, by strength of Understanding, and industrious Enquiry, early perform'd this great Task, and freed your self from those Principles instill'd into you in your Youth; which would have made you incapable of being a good Subject and a great Patriot in your riper age; and have since became so eminent in both characters, that every man that heartily loves the constitution of our English Government, has a profound Respect and Veneration for your Lordship.

Nor will your share of Honour deserve to be less in History than that of the bravest of your Ancestors▪ since none could ever more freely adventure Life, Estate and Honour for their Countreys Freedom than your Lordship did. And it appears to me to be much a greater Glory to be highly instrumental in the Redemption of ones own, than in the Conquest of another. And I beseech your Lordship pardon this interruption of your business or diversion, from him who is, without any mixture of fawning, most sincerely,

closer.signed:
Your Lordships most obedient
Humble Servant.

list.head: Drammatis Personae▪
list.item: Bernardo, a Spaniard, Collonel of a Regiment in Flanders, a vapouring blustring Souldier. Mr. Vnderhill.
Luscindo, his Son, a well-bred Gentleman, and a man of Honour. Mr. Williams.
Doristeo, a young Gentleman of Gallantry and Courage. Mr. Bowman.
Finardo, his Friend. Mr. Alexander.
Tegue O Divelly, an Irish Fryer. Mr. Leigh.
Hernando, a Gentleman that waits upon Bernardo. Mr. Boen.
Diego, Bernardo's Servant; his Barber. Young Lee.
Sancho, Doristeo's Servant.
Belliza, the Amorous Bigottee. Mrs. Corey.
Elvira, her Daughter. Mrs. Iordan.
Rosania, her Neice. Mrs. Bracegirdle.
Grycia, the old Governante. Mrs. Orsborne.
Levia, a fine Courtezan. Mrs. Butler.
Gremia, her Aunt. Mr. Noakes.
Bravos and Servants.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: SOme of our Authors special Friends will say,
That the whole Audience is trepann'd to day,
And for a new, shall find a damn'd old Play.
He on a Spanish Plot once writ before,
And some the Priest with great impatience bore;
But tho the Party took it much amiss,
They had not the good breeding then to hiss.
Our own Sir Roger on the Stage appears,
And why should not a foolish Priest of theirs?
On that foundation then he built, 'tis true,
But like Drake's Ship, 'tis so repair'd 'tis new;
Newer than his Contemporaries show,
Who all to Novels or Romances owe,
And from whose Native Springs nought e're did flow.
Nor should you his of Barrenness accuse,
Who grac'd the Thefts of any other Muse
Nor tye him up alone to new invention;
And if to want of Wit 'tis no pretension
To lose, he's sure 'tis none to gain the Pension.
But hold, my business now is to declare
Against Bear-garden Hissers open War;
He d'at is after Hishing in dish plaash,
I'le Shing Lilli-burlero in his faash.
Not the brave Wolsely can do more in quelling,
Those nimble Teagues with Men of Inniskilling,
Than I subduing these; for at the Head,
Of our brave Party, I will look them Dead.
But to prevent much Brutal Hiss and Stamp,
Send out the fiercest Champion of your Camp:
Let me the proudest of the Hissers see,
I'le make him know he is no Match for me;
Soon shall the Lists your doubty Warriour quit,
Taught by my single Courage to submit.
You might have better Words, were it not plain
The gentlest usage of you is but vain;
E'n take your course, our Poet bid me say,
If all of you be such dull Fools to pay
For being displeas'd, come and Hiss every day.
If good the Play, your Hisses will be vain;
If bad, no Claps its weakness can sustain.
If this be lost, he's not of all bereft,
He hopes he still shall have some credit left
He's sure by this his Friends he shall not lose,
And keeping them he cares not for his Foes.

div.head: Plays Printed for James Knapton, at the Crown in St. Paul's Church-yard.

list.item: SQuire of Alsatia.
Bury-Fair.
The True Widow: Comedies. Written by Tho. Shadwell.
The Fortune-Hunters: Written by Mr. Carlile.
Mr. Anthony: Written by the Earl of Orrery.
Widow Ranter: Written by Mrs. A. Behn.
English Frier, or the Town-Sparks: Written by Mr. Crown.
The Devil of a Wife: Written by Mr. Ievon.

Pope Ioan: A Tragedy.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: WHere's my Mother, Rosania?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: In her Closet Cousin, where should she be?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Close at her Beads I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: She has been very devout since Horatio went off from his Honourable proposals of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Thou art a mischievous Girl, art not thou asham'd to railly thy good Aunt so?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Well, she has been most grievously devout ever since his apostacy, to the vexation of us all: But shou'd he turn about again, she wou'd soon lay down her Beads, and quaver to her Guitarr, like an old Spinstress to a Wheel.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes, and discard the Irish Fryar, Father Tegue and his Lay Brother, for a brace of unclean Tyre-women: 'Tis somewhat hard to set ones heart upon the other World, till we grow unfit for the uses of this.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Very true, for my part, I believe there are none weary of the World, till the World are weary of them; the World begins with them first.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Thou art in the right; methinks it is a very pretty World; they may talk what they will of Vanity, the most pious Christians in Madrid are loth to leave it.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I am resolv'd for my part, to have a good opinion of the World, till the World has an ill opinion of me; and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Gryc.
sp.p: Mrs. Rosania, my Lady calls for you.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I go.

sp.speaker: Elvi.
sp.p: Pray say I am retired, here's my office.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Madam, the Ghostly Fathers are with my Lady.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Now is their time indeed; have they no Collation?

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Lord Madam, that you shou'd ask that, when were they here without one?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Good men, they are content to suffer here on Earth, and with much eating and drinking, they painfully consult about affairs of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Will you not go to 'em, and take part of what they eat and talk?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
No; much good may't do my Mother with her Irish Hypocrite, the
Reverend Father Tegue O Divelly; I have at present no Stomach to Sweetmeats or Confessors. Office lye thou there, and now to my Novella's.
Exeunt Ros. and Gryc. So, to my wish, I am alone, and now can freely think of him who has so often Charm'd me. Hah, what Madness is this to fall in Love with one I know not! Nor does he know me, or my Love! Oh, if his Mind be like his Body, (and certainly it must be so) 'twill justifie my passion to the World. But let me see Cervantes, what sayst thou? Ha, who s there? whither now?

div.stage: Elvira shuffles Cervantes under the Cushion, and takes up the Office.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: The good men are gossiping with my Lady, and zealously expecting a recruit of Sweetmeats.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Good men, they thrive well, and grow fat upon Mortification. But now to my Legend of Lovers. She walks and Reads. Ha Madam, that was a subtil way of discovering your passion, but it will not serve in my case. But I must find some means to let him see my face, and if he like it, so, if not, mercy on me, I dare not think on what must follow.
Let me see.
sp.stage: She pulls out her Pocket Glass.
sp.p: Ha! what noise is that?
sp.stage: She puts up her Glass hastily.
sp.p: These Liquorish Priests dispatch their Sweetmeats with as much haste as a hunted Bear would a Honey-Pot.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: The Fathers (at present up to the knuckles in Jelly of Quinces, with three or four Bottles of the richest Wines) desire your sweet company.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Tell 'em I am retir'd, and can't come.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Novella's and a Pocket glass instead of Beads and Office.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Get you gone Huswife, you grow as mischievous as a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Well, well, l'le leave you to your pious Meditations, Farewel.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Let me see, will this Face do any Execution, [Elv. takes up the Pocket Glass.] If it will, look to thy Heart, my unknown Gallant. The Poets call these hairs our Snares and Nets; if they be l'le set them, let who will be entangled with them—Now for my Patches, these are to Powder our Ermin Skins with;—ha, my dear unknown Love, have at thee.

div.stage: Enter Belliza, Father Tegue and Lay Brother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Bless me Father! what use she makes of her Retirements! these are her Devotions.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Have they caught me, I'me undone.

div.stage: She shuffles away her Glass and Novella's.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Come Mistress I'le see what you have here, Belliza finds the Book. Benedicite! what's here? a wicked and profane Love Book; good Father, I besecch your Reverence, make her Heart ake with pennance for this.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: In trot it is great pitty of dee, and a great faable, by my shoul I vould have all handsome Ladies dewout indeed▪ and I do love to put my Eye upon dem, and maake a great faash upon dem, when I do instruct dem, indeed gra.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I do love to caast de look upon de pretty Laady indeed, vid pious meditaation, and consideraation dat Heaven did maake dem sh • handshom gra.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good holy Man, we are bound to admire the works of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Teg.
Bell.
sp.p: This is a sweet preparation in procession week, to be pruning your self, like an unclean Bird.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Phaat will I spaake unto you for dese spotts and blemishes upon dy shweet faash gra, arrah I vil maake you do de greaat pennance for dish.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What's the reason Father I may not wear patches?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Aboo, boo, boo, what am I dat dou dosht maake expostulaation, and demand a Reason of mee?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: One that has it not about him.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Reashon of mee, dou dosht maake indignaation and affront upon me, by my shoulwation. Am I not a Priesht, and vil I give a Reashon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Twas wickedly done to affront the good Man so.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Have I Converted sho many Hereticks dogs and was sho deep in our braave Plott, and had like to have bin after being slain upon a Gibbet, and been a great Martyr for de Plott, and dosht dou require a Reashon of mee?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Why wou'd you escape? You wou'd ha' done great service to the Church, by being hang'd for it, no doubt Sir a man of your Reverence.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I vill agree vid dee upon daat, but I do not caare for being hang'd, it dosh maake a Priest look sho like a Beasht and a Dogue indeed, and besides I vould not be hang'd but vid a with, as our Forefathers in Ireland us'd to be Hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou'rt a right Sanctified Man; and Heav'n be prais'd for thy deliverance.

sp.speaker: 'Teag.
sp.p: Ah good shoule dou vilt be a greaat Shaint indeed joy. I vil tell unto dee I did escaape because I did deshire to be a Caardinal, and by my Shoulwaation I tink I vill be a Caardinal before I vill have Death, dere has not bin one Eerish Caardinal a great while, I did Plot as well, and cou'd hang as well as de best of dem, but if I bee a Caardinal I know what I vill do.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Well I am corrected, I will never ask a reason of you more, I wou'd as soon beg of a Spanish Souldier.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Do not, for de Church is infaallible, and de Pope is infaallible, and de Caardinals are infaallible, and I vill spake more unto you, de Prieshts are infaallible too. And I shay blesh dy shweet Faash from patches, dou hasht a pretty Faash pull of dese Spots, He pulls them off and Chucks her under the Chin. I wou'd not veare patches upon my faash for de Vorld indeed joy, no sait vould I not. By my shoul she's a brave Lady—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The wisest may sometimes be loosers by their scruples.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I do not caare for all dat I vil be content vid mine own Faash, vid out patches fait and be Abo'o! dou haasht shome upon dy breasht joy I vill put dem off.

div.stage: He presses her breast, she resists.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What do you do, hold off.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh wicked Child! do you resist the good Man?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: By my shoul I vill take dem off, Mash it is gallant Flesh and Blood, Ab'oo, I cannot bear it, farewel I will meet dee upon de prado!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go to, you have angred the good Man, Grycia!

sp.speaker: Gryc.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Get our Vails, we will make visits to the Saints at several Churches.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Put on thy Hat Hernando, thou hast been too long my Fathers good Servant, not to be my Companion, and art to have the next Commission that falls in my Flanders Regiment.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: I shall ever be your Servant: but Sir.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Thou mutterst and art angry with me, prithee speak thy mind with freedom.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: I am angry with you because I love you.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Thou hast wit and courage, and I know thou lov'st me.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Pox on this insolent Curtezan for me.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Wilt thou not allow me one folly.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Not when that folly allows you nothing of your self. Doat upon a Wench, jealous, vex'd, and disquieted for a Wench!

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Speak with more Reverence of a Wench, why from Mexico to Iapan, is there such a joy, such a comfort as a Wench: What do Kings War for but for power, and power for what? To have what Concubines they please, there's the end. What do we Officers fight for, but for Money and a little Honour, to get a Wench? what have Priests, Bishops and Cardinals profits and Dignities, but to procure Wenches? Is there a man in Spain, Lay or Spirititual without a Wench, who has Wit or Money enough to get one? And then to speak thus irreverently of one!

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir,—I wou'd have a Wench to please me, but not to trouble me.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Of all our Art and Industry, our toyl and hazard, Woman's the sweet end; who wou'd give a doyt to govern Men, but by that means to have power over Women?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: A Gentleman may have a little innocent lust, or so, but to fall in love, and with a Mercenary thing.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Thou art no Philosopher Hernando, prithee what is Love? why nothing but great Lust.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Oh sye Sir; Your true Lover sighs and pines, and seeks out shady Groves, and murmering Brooks, and tells his mournful tale, with Arms a cross to Eccho, and never thinks his Mistriss is a Woman, but a Goddess.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: No where but in Romances, why there's no diversion or conversation in Madrid, but with a Curtezan. The men are too grave (not to be uncivil and saydull) and the honest Women are lockt up; besides none in Spain are so well bred as your Curtezans, Hernando, no more.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Why will you put your self in pain because you think another Courts this Levia, and she is wavering, there are others as handsome in Madrid, see her no more

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p:
Pain is but a relishing bit, to make us taste our pleasure better; she has made me jealous, which spurs up my restive Love, that wou'd have Jaded
otherwise whilst she lov'd only me, I cou'd have lov'd another, but now she loves another, I can love none but her.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: A very pretty riddle, make her believe you love another and she perhaps may then love none but you.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: I have it in my Head, come along with me to her, thou shalt see me use her scurvily, and try what that will do.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: You know how angry your Father will be.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Let what will come on't, I will go through.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: I have stood by you when Bullets have whistled about our Ears, and will not leave you now.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Are you stark mad Neice, by your extravagance to lose the finest, properest, kindest and most liberal Lover in Madrid.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Come Aunt, you understand not my business:

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Go to Mistress; I not understand a Womans business with a Man, that's fine.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Nay I must confess you have been us'd to bring the Young together, and make meer strangers Friends.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Oh cry you mercy, have I so, I'le breed no bate nor division between young People, if they agree not in their Youth, they'l hardly be brought together in their Age.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: You can procure the beginning of Love; but know not how to make that Love continue.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Marry come up, you shall keep School and teach new tricks to Widows above Fifty, did not I take you a poor sorry Girl, out of your Mothers hands, rest her Soul, she little thought what preferment you wou'd come to? did not I bestow all Accomplishments of good breeding to fit you for a shining Mistriss in Madrid?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Well Aunt.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: And has not Heav'n blest my endeavours, and made you a very Paragon. And you with your extravagance to cast away the fruit of all my care and Prayers for you.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Why so froward Aunt, what all Age, and no Gravity?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You will make me Gray with sorrow.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Luscindo began to cool upon my fondness, and seek out new Adventures; and I'm resolv'd to plague him for't.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You say you Love him?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Yes, with such madness as admits no rest.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: And will you anger him?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Yes, therefore, if we don't season our love with anger sometimes, 'twill be too luscious, and men will surfeit of it.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Well I have another Neice who shall obey me, but pray make ready to Mass, you will consider the day I hope; I shall never live to neglect good days, how can we look for a blessing upon our endeavours else. Here he comes, why Neice.

div.stage: Enter Luscindo and Hernando at one door, Doristeo and Finardo at the other.

sp.speaker: Levia.
sp.p: Let me alone, by Heaven I will have my own way, Fa, la, la, la, are you there, were you sent for?

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: No, had I been so, 'tis ten to one I had not come.

sp.speaker: Levi.
sp.p: Y'are very haughty on the sudden Sir.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Where is the pretty Miss that I must treat for?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Bless me do you know what day 'tis, and what week, you make me tremble, will you make no difference of days, Benedicite?

sp.speaker: Dorist.
sp.p: A very pious Bawd.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Upon a Holy-day in a Holy week, have you no conscience, have you no grace left?

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Be not transported, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Ne're tell me, I must serve Heaven sometimes as well as Minister to the necessities of young Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dorist.
sp.p: Be not so hot, but hear me but one word.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: 'Lass I must confess Gallants will have occasion sometimes, but then they must be sure to choose fit days.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Madam, I must be possest of Levia, I cannot live without her, she is yonder, she seems fall'n out with her Gallant, and has of late given me some hopes.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: My love like the wind shall never stay long in a Corner.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: I am pleas'd so it never blows on me again.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: What does he mean? I'le try him to the quick.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Did you give her my Letter, Hernando?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Yes, and she Kiss'd it as eagerly as if she wou'd have swallow'd it.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: What was she doing?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Singing to her Guittar, with such a ravishing Melody I know not which exprest more skill, her Voice or Fingers, but they both excell'd all I have ever heard, her Face, her Mine, her Shape beyond all paralell.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Thou ly'st, base parasite and pimp, she is some Dowdy Quean.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Good, she resents it to the full, and cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: What have I done? I shall blow up my whole design by showing Anger; Ha, ha, ha, this is a pretty tale indeed, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: For old acquaintance sake, I cou'd not conceal my good Fortune from you, and now you know the reason of my coming I shall take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: And as a sign that I have been provident, behold? kind Doristeo excuse me: the parting with a tedious old friend whom I shall ne're see more, has made me not so civil to my new one as I ought.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My dear, my sweet, I am transported.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Pox on't, where's my Mistress; I'd fain be transported too.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: (aside) Ha, ha, ha, this touches him I see. (to Dor.) Let your Coach attend here after Mass, we'll see the Pictures which came from Rome: And in the Evening we'l drive in the Parado.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Death shall I bear this?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: S' Heart Sir are you mad? will you spoil your own design by being angry, laugh Sir, laugh, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Aside. Walk this way a little. To Dotisteo. Ah Luscindo, I have thee fast upon the Hook, and I will play with thee.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Madam, there is a Lady will revenge our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Ile not do thee the honour to laugh at thee.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Come, where are you young Gentlewomen? to Church, come on.

sp.speaker: Minia.
sp.p: Here Madam.

div.stage: [Exeunt Doristeo, Finardo, Gremia, Levia and Minia.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: This haughty Curtezan by her Pride, is a Mistriss fit for none but Lucifer himself?

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: I am provok'd to the disordering of my Temper: But I shall not want occasion of that, Don wants not Courage.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: 'Life Sir fear nothing, you may be sure of her Love, by her anger; she swell'd at what I told her like a Dutch Trumpeter, she had fire in her face, and flames in her Eyes.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Let's see which way they go.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Sir if you dog her, you're undone; in Love as in War, they that strike first, have the worst on't: You must dodge like an Old General.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Well she shall not be too hard for me, I will have my will on her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why Daughter, Oh wicked Girl, what wandring eyes you fling about you, whom wou'd you entangle? Why Rosania! you wanton Minx, you are stareing up at every Window, like an Indian who had never seen a City. A modest Maid shou'd have no other object but the ground▪

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The Earth is a prospect for Beasts, and Heaven for us Madam.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me always look upon my Nose, and learn to squint?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: If you always look'd upon the ground, how did you get a Husband?

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: By the reputation of my modesty, I was indeed forc'd. My inclination was to a Nunnery, why Rosania?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I was only looking at a Balcony to see a young Gentleman play with a Ladies Fan.

sp.speaker: Bell▪
sp.p: How now, have you your distinctions already, and observe who is Young and Old.

div.stage: Enter Father Tegue and Lay Brother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Father, we walk'd softly, waiting for you here.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I vill tell de Laady what I have seen indeed, all dee Shaints are in dere besht Apparrel, and are very brave Joy, arrah my Lady, it vould do good to your Heart in your Body, to shee dem dat I have sheen.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: This is a very silly Fellow, Rosania.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: A Shick Taylor, has shent a very braave Pettycoat to Shaint Clare, and by my Shoul she does look very gallantly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well that good Taylor may be an Example to us all, who ever he be, I'le warrant him a good Soul, and a devout Workman.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Oh yes, Taylors are very honest, phen dey be very sick introt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What else Father have you observ'd?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p:
Why Shaint Teresia, has new habitts from Cap a pie shent from Paris, I tell you she is now ash fine and braave, as e're a Shaint in Madrid, no dishpraise
to any; she may show her Faace before dem all; phat vill I shay more?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'me glad on't, for to say truth, 'twas a shame to keep her so poor and Thredbare upon Holy days, and I may say in private, without shifts of under Linnen.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Now she's Dead, and can neither work nor beg for her self.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Dou shayst vel Daughter, it vas a great pitty and a shaame and a great Faable too.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Cousin, Cousin, methinks yonder is the finest Gentleman I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I have order'd my Coach to be here about, and I must wait for my humorous Mistress, she may be as slippery as an Eele for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Did you ever see so delicate a Man?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Oh yes, many a one.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I am sure you never did, it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Ah ha Cousin art thou thereabouts?

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Who can that young Lady be, that fix'd her Eye upon you, as if she wou'd dart you through.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I cannot imagine, she has the brightest Eye I ever saw, and a Mine beyond any of the Sex. I am resolv'd I'le have her dogg'd, but let us not seem to mark them.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: He minds us not.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sure I shall be so happy to have one sight of my Love, at some of the Churches.

div.stage: All this while Bell. is kissing the Friers Beads and paying great Reverence to them.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Pox on this Curtezan, she vexes me at heart.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Ha, this is he, there's no other like him.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Can you not guess Cousin, what fine Gentleman that was ev'n now?

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: What shape, what motion's there? If her face be answerable, she threatens Death to all who look on her, she seems to observe us!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I am resolv'd to try if my face can conquer him, who with such force has vanquisht me.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: If I cou'd get but one glimpse of her face.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I'le drop my Handkerchief, sure he will take it up and give it me.

div.stage: [Drops her Handkerchief, Luscinda takes it up.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Madam, vouchsafe a moment but one look.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What is your meaning Sir?

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to accept this little service, this Handkerchief dropt from you Madam.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: From me Sir, you are mistaken, sure, I'le search; the truth is Sir, mine is missing, but I think mine had not so fair a Lace.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: It can be none but yours Madam.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I'le put it up in hope it may be mine; but if you hear of one who has more right to't; I live in Garden-street at the Blue and Gold Balcony, near the House of Don Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: He is my Father, most Divine Creature.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: His Father?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why Elvira, where are you? There are Gallants here, bless us, Temptation is approaching, Fly.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Ah Cousin, I find something, that I had not this way to give a sample of my self!

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: By Heaven she is the brightest thing I ever saw.

div.stage: Priest, Lay Brother, Elvira and Rosania.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: If ever any Angel wore a Petticoat, this may be one.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: The World has not a Beauty like her, I am all on Fire.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: And Sir I can tell you some news which may make well for you; your Father is resolv'd not to return to Flanders, but to Marry the devout Widdow Belliza, who undoubtedly is this Ladies Mother, what think you now of Levia?

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Name not that paltry thing, this beauty came from Heaven.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: And truly▪ the other Beauty is going to Hell.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: As suddenly as Lightning she struck, and as soon vanish'd, she has kindled in me in a wild and desperate flame; and I am resolv'd I will possess her or perish in the attempt.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: CAst not your wandring Eyes on either hand, Ile lead, pray follow one another singly; and look strait forward thus.

div.stage: Enter Doristeo and Finardo, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Like Mules in a Draught.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Look forward thus, quoth she, wou'd my Aunt have one of us look like her.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a little unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: D' yee hear young ones.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What wou'd I give to have one glimps of this unknown Mistriss, or to find who she is.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: I thought your known Mistriss might have been enough for you for some time.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There's no comparison betwixt an adventure and a purchase, especially where the Mistress seems the Aggressor.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Yes, for an Adventure you may have your Throat cut, for your purchase you are safe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come follow me as I direct you.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I am ruin'd, the sight of this young Cavalier has put me into wildness and confusion▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why you Minx, I see you there; whither do you throw your wicked Glances?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: She is her Daughter by the authority she exercises over her.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: What e're come on't he shall see my Face.

div.stage: [She stumbles and falls down on her hands and knees, Dor. steps in and helps her up, she shows her Face as if by accident.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Tho' I'm sorry for your misfortune, yet I'm glad I was so happy to have the honour to serve you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Your Civility deserves my thanks Sir, which I heartily return and wish it in my power to requite.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Heaven, Complements and showing her Face to a Man the Saints defend us, you are defiled, get you gone Huswife before me; I shall set a Watch upon you; avoid Sir, come not near.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Blame not common Civility Madam, if I had given her a fall you might be angry, but not for helping of her up when she was down.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fly, fly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: She is the most surprizing Beauty I ever saw, she has struck me to the heart; Sancho follow at some distance till you find where she goes in.

sp.speaker: Sancho.
sp.p: I need not do it I know her Mother, it is Belliza the Biggotte Widow that lives at the Blue and Gold Balcony, in Garden street.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: She shall soon hear from me, and as I guess it will not be unacceptable, this Levia will tarnish and grow dull upon my hands; I ne're knew Love before this day, these killing Beams have pierced me thro' and thro'.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: For my part I'm for good safe Wenching, without Knight errantry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Thou hast a gross unelevated fancy, 'tis difficulty makes the pleasure high and racy.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Well I can eat my Venison without venturing my Neck to Hunt it down, 'tis want of appetite that requires such circumstances.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If I cou'd enjoy the whole Sex as easily as one Wife, there would be no pleasure in 'em all; the whole Sex wou'd be but one Wife.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Then farewel Levia.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, I may have a long Journey to this Paragon, and must be forced to bait by the way. Besides in this Race I have Rival strains against me, and I'm resolv'd to whip and spur against him.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Are you so, this is fine what will become of my reputation, what scandal will be brought upon me and my yet unblemisht House; for two of you to fall out like Ruffians, and perhaps Murther one the other, for a Damsel of my bringing up; but lle prevent you if I can, Oh wicked men upon such a day too!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: lle hear no more teasing, yonders my Coach attends on Levia, lets away.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p:
Oh she's a wicked Girl, and breaks my heart with obstinacy.
Enter Tegue o' Devilly and Lay Brother.
But let me see here's, the good Irish Father, I will endeavour to interest him in my affair; good Father stay and let your reverence attend my story which concerns your Function▪

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Out and awoyd my presence I vill loose my Reputaation, if I vill be after spaaking vid dee in de Street indeed.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I defie any one to say black's my Eye, I beseech your reverence come into my House.

sp.speaker: Teag.
sp.p: Dy Houshe is of ill report, and day shay dat young People of different Sexes meet dare for Carnal Recreaation indeed by dy appointment, and Assignation Joy.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Alas Father, every Gentleman and Cavalier cannot Marry; it is fit they should be supply'd, and I have now and then bred up one with Civil Education for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Dou shayst vell.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: But I defie all my Neighbours to say that e're we miss our Church, or that ever I suffer any Man to come within my doors upon a Vigil or Fast; and ne're a Woman in Madrid observes Lent and Fish days more strictly.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Dou dosht spaake like unto a good pious voman indeed, if dou dosht observe dy Lents, dy Wigils and Embers, dou dosht vell.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I wou'd not break one of 'em for the World.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I believe dou art a very good Laady, and dosht love de Church, vel joy, as dou shayst every one cannot Marry; and Fornicaation is Venial but vee vil pass by some Peccadillo's as Shwearing, Wenching, and Lying and de like; in dose who love de Church indeed. Are dese young Gentlewomen handsome dat dou dosht breed up for de Occaasions of de young Cavalliers Joy.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: The very Parragons of all the City, and they Dance with Castanietto's most Charmingly and Sing to the Guittar most Melodiously.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: By my Shoul, a shivil and a good Pious Voman, and I vil go vid a good Priesht my Friend a gallant Man indeed, and vee vil Fornicate and Absolve, Absolve and Fornicate by turns every day at her House, vel I vill come and spaake vid dy Damshels and inshtruct dem joy, phaat vil I shay more.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Bless your Reverence, I beseech you go with me now and hear my story there is like to be Blood shed, which I would intreat you to prevent; it is about a wicked Neice of mine.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Vel since dou dosht observe dy Wigills and dy Fashts, and dosht love de Church I vil go vid dee Joy.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Thanks Holy Father, follow me.

sp.speaker: Teag.
sp.p: Now I vil be after having a very good Strumpett, and I vil maake hashte to Donna Belliza too.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: with a Pocket Glass. Well you have found me out, I'me in Love all over Love; but dost thou think thou art conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
Elv.
sp.p: Pish he a Charming Man Oh my Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Pish too good Cousin, there's no comparison betwixt 'em.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No, lle be sworn is there not, do not provoke me to forget my Friendship and Relation.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Pray Cousin do not anger me, who am as much concern'd for one, as you can be for the other.

div.stage: Enter Belliza, and snatches the Glass from her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Bless me, ungracious Girl, are you always at your Pocket Glass, you are resolv'd to be no stranger to your countenance, if this be a true intelligencer.

sp.speaker: Elvir.
sp.p: Wee shou'd know our selves, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How Mrs. Pert, what by a Looking-glass, this comes of your Novella's, they put fine thoughts into your head, how to please a Man, and all dressing, patching, and curling is at a Man; the Saints defend us.

sp.speaker: Elvir.
sp.p: Did Saints never use Looking-glasses.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: If they did not, they were scurvily drest I warrant 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You Mrs. Male-pert, I hear you have not been at Confession this fortnight: I will make you confess, Huswife, to Father Tegue who will be here soon: withdraw, and prepare your self for it.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Why shou'd Old fellows know the Secrrts of the Young? But it must be so, I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now Vanity, this is to inform you, what force and strength your Beauty hath to conquer men with, and if you pursue that Train of thoughts: Heaven bless us! whether do they carry us?

sp.speaker: Elvir.
sp.p: Sure 'tis lawful to adorn our Faces, and we had better have our own Opinions, than our Maid's in the matter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, what d' yee think when you adorn, as you call it? But to please some Man with that, and its appurtenances. A modest Maid shou'd hide her Beauty from the World.

sp.speaker: Elvir.
sp.p: To what purpose, is it given her then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le take care, your Jewel shall be a Prisoner in my Close.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Madam, Don Bernardo, the great Officer lately come from Flanders, bid me say he has business with you, and desires admittance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With me! it cannot be; alas, I have given over all Business.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: 'Tis true Madam, I assure your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Elvir.
sp.p: I can tell you more, my Maid had it in a whisper from one of his Servants, that he is become your Lover.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Lover, Ha, ha, ha, No, no, didst thou say so Elvia.

sp.speaker: Elvir.
sp.p: I protest Madam, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good lack, how troublesome Men are.

sp.speaker: Elvir.
sp.p: There's no such inconvenience in the Match, He's rich, and a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay I should be loth to do any Man wrong by too hasty an Exception, what manner of Man is he, I never saw him?

sp.speaker: Gryc.
sp.p: A goodly proper comely Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To think of me, good lack a day, a Widow of my long abstinence.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Why so Mother, you are in the prime of your Age.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's true, but on the sudden, when I am so ill drest; where have you left him?

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: In the drawing Room, what shall I say to him Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Perhaps he did not mean to surprize me, say lle attend him soon; what manner of Glass is this?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: A very true one Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's the reason you make so much on't, ha.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: 'Tis to examine our defects; but you have none, pray give it me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No no, if that be the use on't, 'tis good to Examine our defects.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Let me hold it Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Lord how like the Image of Negligence shall I look, there's no elegance at all in my Dressing.

div.stage: [Bell. makes ridiculous Grimaces, and prinks her self at the Glass.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I'le put your hair in order.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do Daughter, we shou'd be orderly.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You see Madam, Glasses sometimes may be necessary.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, to set out our selves somewhat, to stir up or provoke a Person to Conjugal affection, prithee how do I look to day humph?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Your Face is very powerful, exceeding moving.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Really is it truly! fetch my best scented Gloves, my Pastils and Pomanders?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And a little health to lay in your Cheeks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By all means.
Love to me, blessing on's Heart, to me! but I must contain my joy.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Here Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why dost thou smile Girl?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: To think how little you car'd for a Young Husband at my years, that grow so warm at the approach of an Old Collonel at yours.

sp.speaker: Bell.
Elv.
sp.p: Methinks a Husband should guard my Honour better than a Father-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, who knows but the addresses the Father makes to me, may breed in time some good Occasion between the Son and you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Well chanc't, as if you knew my heart good Mother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Farewel, I'le lay Red on at the Glass in my Chamber, be sure be not you seen.

sp.speaker: Teag.
sp.p: Shweet Laady the Shaints blesh dee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good Father I'm busie.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Busy, phaat vidout me,
I vil not bear this, no fait will I not, to put contempt and Indignaation upon me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What's the matter Father?

sp.speaker: Teag.
sp.p: Dee matter! dosht dou not shee de maater; she did slight my Salutaation and vou'd not spaake a vord to me, and by my fait she hash put de outshide of de door upon me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Indeed it is very hard.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: By my Soulvaation is it. I vil go upon my faash in de business vith her, and vill speak plaain vords to her, very Teeth, and her Faash too; I do not caare for her, if she vil put de out-shide of the door upon me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: She has great business, for Collonel Don Benardo is come to make Love to her.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Ha, hoo, hoo, hoo, vil she taake dose toughts of Flesh upon a Fish day indeed, phaat vil I shay? By my Shoul I vil make I ennance unto her, that vil make her groan upon dish occaasion.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: May a Woman not think upon a Husband on a Fasting day?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Is not a Husband Flesh indeed, you do not take him for Fish do you you must not put Flesh into any part of your Body upon a Fish day indeed: But I vil spaake no more; have I done so much for de Caatolick Church, and am I thus affronted in this plaash.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Why what have you done for the Church?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: phaat vil I shay unto you dere is my Paaper that vil maake Testificaation upon me, and I believe I vil be a Caardinal, or a Shaint at least indeed.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What's this I can't read it.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I vil reshite it unto you, it is a Lisht of Heretiks names that I did reconshile phan I was in England, and I vil speake a proud vord unto any Jesuits faash dat shimple as I shtand here, I did bring over more than any shix of them.

sp.speaker: Imprimis,
sp.p: Of Chambermaids dat vas maade vid Child by their Laadies Husbands, or, their Laadies Sons. Two and Taarty.

sp.speaker: Item,
sp.p: Of Caash-keepers, dat did run avay vid de money, and some broken wing'd Shopkeepers. Eighteen.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Three Masters of Colleges, and shix Fellows.

sp.speaker: Item,
sp.p: Of Whores, Eighty two.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: That's a jolly Number indeed. I see you kept ill company, Father.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: It was for deir shoules, indeed Joy.

sp.speaker: Item.
Elv.
sp.p: Did you make all these good Catholicks?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Yes, braave Catholicks, gallant Catholicks Fait and Trott.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Of ancient faat women, day call Bawds, Thirty shix.

sp.speaker: Item.
sp.p: Of Knights of de posht. Fourty.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What are those Knights of the Post?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Phy it is a great Order of Knighthood which they have in England, but day shwarm in Ireland.

sp.speaker: Item,
sp.p: Of Cookmaids. Two.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: How comes that number so small?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: De Cookmaid find de greaat trouble in dressing de Fish, and day do not caare for fish days. All dese have I reconshile, and to be thus affronted; I vil go and meditate upon Revenge, and my Nature is Vindicative.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I long to steal into the wooing between this mighty Collonel and my Mother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good noble Collonel be more considerate, this is not like the Spanish Conversation.

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: No Madam, I have learn'd better things in France, and in the Netherlands: We men of War are not for words, I love to march up close to friends of foes, 'tis all one to me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By your carriage, I know not which you take me for.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I take all for Foes, till they have yielded.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Hold hold, good man of steel, pray keep the Peace.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: This I suppose is your Trinket; Hernando, entertain her nimble chopps

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Your man, know Old Gentleman I'm too good for his Master.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Old Gentleman! peace Child peace; had the prodest Grandee in Madrid call'd me Old, he had, by my beard, e're this fallen by my hand.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Pray, let your Valour spare my Aunt and me.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Her Neice, ha! I will not mind her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray be not so pert, young Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: This young Bud interrupts us; be pleas'd to require her abscence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How Sir, shall a sincere widow of my Reputation, be in Company with a Collonel alone? you have leave to speak, Sir; do you minx, hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: You must excuse the heartiness of men of my profession, when I charge I love to charge home, as all Europe knows.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Home, ay Madam, my Master always charges thro' and thro', routs every party, and levels all that are before him, he loves no Musick like the whistling of Bullets, and no perfume like the smoke of Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I was ever given to Valour, and Magnanimity from my Youth upwards, and everlov'd to take a Fort or Cittadel by storm, therefore consider Madam, what you do.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: He intends to make Love with fire and sword, Madam, have a care of him.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Again, my little Blossom.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Stand off, what would you fight my Aunt?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Peace Huswife, I doubt not, but you are a gallant Commander as I have heard, but what is all this discourse to me?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: He talks of his Valour, why they are always beaten by the French.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Voto, have a care, provoke me not, here stands the man, that always stood, and never ran, as can witness Monts, Seneff, Stratsburg, &c. my Regiment of Horse of four hundred.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Being at least, Eight and Thirty effective men.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What's all this Valour to me? (aside) He mentions not one word of Love.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: You hear Madam he can praise himself sufficiently, but cannot find in his heart to give your Ladyship a good word.

sp.speaker: Bern
sp.p: But come sweet Widow, what do we trifle for? (He stands up close to her.) I hate this pickeering; Let's lay aside our forlorn hopes, and let our bodies joyn.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Help, help, my poor Aunt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, methinks you are too abrupt; this is not civil.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: In Affairs of Love, he that shews most Love is most civil; and we cannot show it more than by eagerness and haste: Treaties of Conjugal Affection are always short and pithy. A word to the wife: Don Bernards D' Alcantara would make Donna Belliza his Spouse, and enjoy her Person incontinently: hah, Widow, sayst thou, hah?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, this roughness of your carriage is somewhat unusual with me; but I suppose this is a fashion of speaking you make use of to many Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Now my Aunt comes home to the point.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Ounds, do you not take me for a man of honour? Bernardo is known all over Europe to be a man of honour: Not take me for a man of honour!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hope I may, Sir; yet men are frail and fickle.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What, love another besides you! You take me for a monster, sure: I'd have you know I'm none of those that are all Love, and no Conscience.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Good Sir do not beat my Aunt, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sweet Prattle-basket be quiet; peace little one, or I shall grow passionate. In short, Belliza is young, handsome and rich, Bernardo is rich, brave and honourable, active and sprightly, yet grave and civil.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: The Widow melts like Snow before the Sun.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I have summon'd you; your Flag of Treaty is hung out; we have parley'd: Speak quick, Do you yield, or no? Know, I never had man or woman stand long before me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are a valiant man, I must confess; but your Valour does very much surprize and disorder me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: We must not loyter in Love, what we do we must do heartily.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In truth he seems a hearty Gentleman; Are you in earnest, Sir? Sure you dare not swear what you profess.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: That's home indeed.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes, if your house be strong built, though swearing may seem a little uncivil at my years; yet when my Constancy is touch'd: Let me see, is your main beam strong? let me see: Ay, 'twill do: now have at you; By all the—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, do not swear, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Not swear when my honour and constancy are in question! Voto, I will out-swear the deepest Gamester in Madrid.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In professions of conjugal Love swearing may be lawful.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By the blood of all my Ancestors, by the unblemish'd Honour of my heard.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh horrid Oaths! you make my hair stand an end.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Silence: By all—Heaven! who is this?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are free, Sir, to go on.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: By all the beards of Arragon, an unknown Star.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Daughter, ha, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Is she her Daughter? what ignorant Devil led me to the Mother?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shou'd have stay'd without, I shou'd have told you all.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I am Plannet struck; this is the beauty I must worship: A Pox on the Widow for me; I must get off from my wrong Visit with speed before she expects me to swear again.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How are you, Sir, not well?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: A sudden indisposition; I am troubled with a Fit of—a—Madam, good night.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: What a Devil ails the Old Fellow?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sure this great Souldier has been wounded often in the head, his brain seems somewhat tender.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, Girl, his wound's in the heart; his heart is tender. Good lack▪ did not think my poor remaining beauty had that power.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Pray Madam be civil after mischief, and bring him to the Stairs.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are so forward; pray keep your distance.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh Cousin, I am transported with joy, too mighty for me, I cannot bear it.

div.stage: (She kisses a Letter she has in her hand, very often.)

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Prithee don't run mad, Rosania, thou hast none of the strongest heads.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Look there, read, read, and be happy, for every one who touches that Paper must be so.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Love-madness is the same in all; let me see, this is to me. To the fair Daughter of Belliza.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Look within, the happy messenger that brought it, said, it was for the Lady that fell down; from the Gentleman that help'd her up.

body.p: Madam, The Adventure, as you came from Church, though of little danger to you; yet is like to cost me my Life: The wound I receiv'd by your beauty is mortal, without your help, to

closer.dateline: From my House, in St. Jago-street.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: This is short, but very much to purpose: How came you by this?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: By an holy woman that belongs to the Sisterhood of St. Clare. I'le tell you more, he mistakes me for the Daughter; and unless you give me leave to carry on this Intrigue in your Name, I am a lost creature.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Thou art far gone, I see, poor Rosania, I may trust thee with my Name, thou wilt use it well.

sp.speaker: Res.
sp.p: I'le write instantly. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Oh dull Luscindo, cou'dst thou not apprehend me, or dost thou not like me? Thou, in both cases, art unworthy of me: but I understand his signs too well to think the latter, I wou'd he understood mine as well,
sp.l: Ob how cou'd Love in any shape e're be
Disguis'd so much to make it strange to thee.

sp.speaker: Luse.
sp.p: Oh, Hernando, I am mad till I have discover'd my Passion to my Mistress: 'tis plain enough she made advances: And what a dull Clod of Earth must she think I am who have not design enough to let her know my Love.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Have patience, Sir, some few hours, and if your Father, who is the most vigorous Wooer I ever saw, makes not way for you, I'le do't.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: How, Hernando? for if I find not some way, I'le storm the house, but she shall know I love her.

div.stage: Enter Doristeo, Finardo, Levia, on the other side of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: The Sun is set, and the Prado is cool and pleasant; but I am all on fire.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I never saw a siner Evening: we shall have some curious Fruits, Confections and Lymonades, will you honour me to taste them?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My Servant waits yonder: but, dear Madam, be pleas'd to add to the pleasure of the Evening by charming me, and all the company, with a Song to the Guittar.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: If you can endure it, send for a Guittar.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: We have one ready.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: There she is that's her Voice.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: How the Devil can you think of her?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Revenge, revenge: I am resolv'd to conquer her, then laugh at her. But where's the Lady Estifania, you promis'd should be here?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: At hand, Sir; she is my Mistress, but shall be yours at present, and pray use her civilly; and d'hear, Sir, be sure to let me have her again untouch'd.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Pox on't, this Farce will never take, and if she discovers it, she'll triumph most unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Play you your part, as well as I mine; and I'le venture my Life on't: Come here's your Lady Bright, your Mrs. Estifania.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Ha, she by this light may guess at me, but can't distinguish you▪

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Gently, Sir, this way.

div.stage: (They advance near the Company, they are moving towards the Musick, Levia steps aside towards Luscindo,

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: My dearest Estiphania.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: 'Tis he, he calls her Estiphania: all my Arts are suddenly turn'd upon my self: Hell take him, court her before my face!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What means this sudden, and this strange Distemper, Lady!

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: If he discovers my disgrace, he'l turn a Rebel too. (aside) I feel a sudden faintness in my Spirits, pray help me to some water from you Fountain.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'le run and fetch you some.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you step for some strengthening Spirits, I find cold water will be too weak a Remedy.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: You shall have them instantly.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Musick, though you are in tune, I am not: There's your Cordial, jog off.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Sweet Estifania, wonder of all Widows, Mirrour of thy Sex, thou brightest thing on Earth.

sp.speaker: Estif.
sp.p: You find you are dear to me, who venture my Life and Honour for you. Name not my Name once more; shou'd any one o're-hear it, and carry it to my Brother, I were lost: think on his Quality.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.p: Thou art dearer to me than my Life, and I'le defend thee better. My Passion now exceeds all other mens, as thou out-shin'st the rest of all thy Sex.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Oh that I knew thy Brother.

sp.speaker: Esti.
sp.p: I warrant you have said as kind things to Levia.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.p: Brand me with infamy, if ever I consider'd her, but as a wandring wench, a trifle, only fit for too much leisure.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Thou lyest, thou Villain, thy tongue is black and rotten, as thy heart; I'le have another hand for my revenge on thee, but on this Serpent mine shall serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.p: Do you know the quality and tenderness of this young Lady?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I'le give her marks to be known by.

sp.speaker: Estrp.
sp.p: Pray keep your Nails in, beshrew your heart for never paring 'em.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.p: Stand off, what will you rob her in the dark?

sp.speaker: Esti.
sp.p: Death! the Jade scratches like a Griffon.

div.stage: Enter Doristeo with a glass of Water, after him Finardo with a Vial.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Here's the water, Madam. What d'ye mean?

div.stage: (She snatches it, and breaks the Glass.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Here's the Cordial.

div.stage: Finar presents the Cordial, she does the like.)

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What is it has inflam'd you thus?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: No Cordial can relieve me, nor Water cool my Flame; Nothing can quench it but the Traitors blood; 'tis no time to dissemble now: I esteem'd your Passion, but had no power to answer it, I was so madly engag'd to Luscindo, the worst of men.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I have spent my time well the while.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I frankly own I have dissembled with you▪ to urge his Love by jealousie.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A very pretty account of all my Money.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Now I detest him, and if you'l aid me in revenge, by Heaven you shall entirely govern me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What can he now have done so to provoke you?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: He had the impudence to court a Lady here, even now, before my face, and talkt of me with scorn and hatred.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Do you know his new Mistress?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Nothing of her but what I over-heard ere they were aware on't: He call'd her Estiphania, and Widow; and she talkt of her Brothers Honour, Quality, and her apprehension of his Rage.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Furies and Hell, Finardo, this Description can agree with none but my Sister.

sp.speaker: Fm.
sp.p: It cannot be, she is a woman of Honour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Woman and Honour, pish, Womans Honour is a Bulrush.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I am infinitely oblig'd to you, that you so soon shou'd interest your self in my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes I'le revenge: (to Dor.) Shall he think because I make Love to a Courtezan here of his, to wound the Honour of my Family? His Life shall pay for't

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I see you are wound up to high Resentments of my injury, I shall from, this moment entirely love you, and for ever detest him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pox on this Courtezan, I cannot think on her, my Honour! We'll wait on you home, and then revenge.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Dear Doristeo, now I find you are a Man of Honour.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: IT is not fit Elvira that we trust this impertiment Girl with any Love affair, for I intend her suddenly for a Monastry: Her Fortune then will come to me. [To her self.] Rosania quit the Room.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I go Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wonder Girl at the disorder of the Collonel, that my Autumnal Beauty shou'd so wound him; indeed my Coyness made your Father fall into fainting fits, but now alack, alack.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sure Madam, he is infinitely taken with you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He is the heartiest Lover in Madrid, I'le say that for him; and I have him fast, and as soon as he recovers shall have a visit. The Son may make a very good Husband for you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I shall have no need of a Husband, having such a Father-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come, come, you know not how you will like him.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Too well, I know it; would Heaven that he lik't me as well.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Madam here's a Letter from Don Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I told thee Elvira I had fired him.

sp.speaker: Reads.
sp.p: You are like to have me from Generation to Generation, you first possest my Love, then it succeeded to your Daughter.
What do I read?
Reads. My Estate is your Daughters if she'll make her claim, while I am in perfect senses, which I find I am now, because I have the judgment to Love her.
Perfidious Wretch!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
What can be the matter?Reads.
But if she takes not pitty on me, I shall dye distracted, and my Testament will not stand good in Law. Therefore, let me wake one Visit before I depart, in adoration of her, who is your beautiful Image.
Your most humble Servant Bernardo.
Is there no Constancy in vile Mankind?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What swift change is in you, or in the Collonel?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let me see, his admittance may bring his Son into the House, who they say is a fine handsom Gentleman; who perhaps may be glad of my Person and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Madam you seem disorder'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Surpriz'd I am, but cannot be troubled since you are so concern'd, this inconstant Collonel has transplanted his affection from me to you. Read that.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: reads to her self. Out on him Vile Apostate, and can he think I wou'd be false to my dear Mother?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Me! No, no, Girl think not on that, Bernardo's Rich; and if he presses for a Marriage yield to him.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: How Madam!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It will be convenient I will have it so, dispute not with me; I'le retire and send him his Answer, take him at first, you need no other argument of his inconstancy than his leaving me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What Miracle's this that she can so easily part with a Lover!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh Cousin this wicked Duoena, this Grycia suspects the good Woman who brought the Letter, and has forwarn'd her the House.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I have consider'd this matter, and your using my Name may breed dangerous Consequences.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Say you so, 'tis now too late, I have settled the correspondence; but I intend not to tell her how: I have observ'd a loose Board in our Balcony, and, for fear the Woman shou'd be discover'd, have order'd my dear Doristeo to take his Letters there, and put his Answers under every Night.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Have you written to him?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Some way must be found out to retrieve this business; the least air or this mock Love may ruin me with Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Since you will have it so, I'le rectifie the Error and let Doristeo know who I am.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Come little Daughter! dy Mother sent me to dee to Confess dee.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: To avoid you her self, she sent you to me.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I vill maake de heart in her Body beat, and aake for dat indeed g • a. [To Elv.] Daughter do you awoyd de Plaash. [Ex. Elv.] Now little Pretty Daughter dou must approach vid humiliation, and vid reverence unto mee to dy Confession, and dou musht give dy shelf up unto me gra.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I do Father.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Begin den, and I vill spaake unto de fait and trot she is a braave young Laady indeed by my Shoul I vou'd I vere aafter being in bed vid her.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: With great sorrow and grief of heart, I confess I told my Aunt two lies since I confess last.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Indeed dosh two lies vere one offence gra, arrah Daughter dou musht say Forty Aves and Two Paters, and dou musht faasht tree Holy days for daat indeed joy, dou shou'd Equivocate and maake use of mental Reservaation and keep dy lies for shome great and pious occasion.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I saw a fine Embroider'd Petticoat, and I wisht for it.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: No great matter, yet it is a kind of a Shin too.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: But Reverend Father I beg Heavens and your Pardon, I have laught at you several times.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Ahoo, boo, boo, maake laugh upon me, why didst dou laugh upon me? arrah dou shalt maake great Pennance for dat, dou musht kneel vid dy bare kneesh Naaked upon a cold shtone, one of de longest hours in de phole tay gra, but perhaps I vil take off daat too. I vil not anger her too much [To himself. Now I vil spaake unto dee. Dousht dou not taake great pleasure vid dosh pretty eyes to maake shweet looksh upon shome man or anodder I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh yes, Father, and I was transported this day at the fight of a fine young Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Peash den, dat is very vel, I vil inshite and provoke her. aside. And dou dosht desire shome communicaation in bed some night or anodder vid him I warrant you gra.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Not for the World unless I were Married to him, and then I must confess I shou'd desire it.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: But hold I predee dosht dou not dream shometime of a Man and art pleash'd? by my Shoul her eyes doth worke Fascinaation upon me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yes Father, I do dream very often.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Daat is vel indeed, phaat dosht dou dream?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I dreamt last night that a fine young Gentleman came and took me by the hand.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Very vell, and I warrant dee he did shtroake dy Ame to dy Elbow, dush dush.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yes indeed I dreamt so.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: And he did squeesh dy shweet hand, and kish it hard dush? dush, dush Joy.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Father, what d' ye mean?

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: I do only maake demonstraation phaat dis young man did unto deetrot, By my shoul she has maude great inflamaation upon me, and if she vil not agree and beat under me, I vill maake a raape upon her Body, Aside. But predee spaake didst dou not dream shomphat further?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yes, Heaven forgive me, I did dream that he took me hard about the waste, and did kiss me.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Vell gra, an dou vert not angry vid him Joy?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No, no, I was too well pleas'd Heaven help me.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Phaat he did taake de about middle and did kish de, dush, dush, dush, dush, dush.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Peash de kish of de Priesht vil absolve de prophaane kish of de Lay Maan, vell and he did trow dee downe upon de plaash, I vill show de how.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: No, no, I dreamt not so far.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: He did, dou dousht not spaak right, and I vil show de how by my Shoul; I vill maake a Raape upon her▪

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Help, help, help, help, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Heaven, what's the matter here? Why Father.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Tegue
sp.p: O dear Daughter, help me to hold her, she is poshesht, or obshesht vid an evil Shpirit.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh Madam, I am not possest, he is a wicked wretch, and if you had not come, wou'd have ravisht me.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Oh help, help, how de foul fiend dosh spaake vid in her, vid a hollow woysh?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: This is beyond all impudence and wickedness, Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Listen how hollow and terrible is dee woysh of de fiend.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Avoid, Satan, a dreadful hollow voice: Peace fiend, peace.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: I vill carry her into de next Room, and exorcise her. Laady, dou maysht retire, I varrant de I am shtrong enough, de fiend begins to know me; he vill frighten dy Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Madam, for heaven's sake hear, he is the most wicked Villain.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Benedicits, Avoid Satan, thou malicious fiend, to blast the holy man thus.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Look, look, he appears, and peeps out at her mout, indeed in de shape of a Polecat, dost dou not shee him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, yes, plain; oh what a misery is this, and what distraction will it cause in our Family? Don Bernarda is with my Daughter, and is to be her Husband, let him not hear this.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: I vill turn him out in a moment, conjuro te Demonem.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Get her into some Room at a distance, where the fiend may not be heard, while I retire, and watch the Collonel.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, are you out of your wits, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: By my shoul I vill conjure upon her.

div.stage: (He struggles wich her, to run her into another Room.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh, help, help, ah, ah, murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: By my shoul, Joy, I vill not murder dee.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh impudent Devil!

sp.speaker: Tegue.
Ber.
sp.p: Wonder not, Madam, at my fierceness, we Military men never whine and make love like Ladies eldest Sons, who have been bred out of harms way, but like Cocks of the Game, and are all for dispatch; besides Madam, your Mother and I am agreed.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: How now Cousin, what haste?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh Cousin! this Tegue O Divelly is the wickedst Villain you ever heard of, I'll give you an account by and by.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Hah, my little twig of Beauty are you there? But pray Madam, let her not stop my course of Love, for if it has not vent with me, the ribb'd with Iron I shall crack.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What love to my Cousin? Why she's a young Lady.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Ay, Gad take me, why do I make love to her else? But prithee sweet blossom, contain that nimble Instrument thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: What, a Reverend white-headed, white-hearded old Gentleman with one foot in the grave, make love to a fine young Lady?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Old! because I'm white! why all our Family are so by that time they are of Age, we are known by it, as the house of Austria by long chins, thick lips, and lank flaxen hair. Hernando do you back what I say.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: I warrant you, if any man out lyes me, then I am a Baboon. My Master, Madam, was grey at sixteen; I have known some of 'em grey at Seven: nay some of 'em have been born grey.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Ounds! the Rogue will ruin me with his lyes, this 'tis for a fellow to lye that has no discretion.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: He is pure White and Red, White on his Head, with his Nose full Red, like Aetna's top, that still is flaming with the Snow about it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I shall grow chollerick, Madam: for all these white hairs, I did last Campaign, without Pole, or any thing in my hand, leap a Moat of 20 foot wide, over a Fauxbray.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: (aside.) from thence to the Parapet, at the next standing leap, next to the Glaeis of the Counterscarp, and then whipt over the Pallizado's.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Oh, Rogue, have a care.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Pish, they understand me not: you shall see, he took the Counterscarp about his middle, and the Bastion in his hand, and, whip, he took the Town in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: A Pox on this Rogue, why sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: And I will not lose my life for any man living, Madam, my Master is a man of the greatest activity of any man in the Army; I am sure he will put off the Spanish gravity when he runs away.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: He tells you true, Madam, I was noted for it all over the Camp.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Can you creep through a Hoop, Sir?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: He shall do't with any man in Europe; I'le go see for a Hoop, he shall do it presently.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why sirrah, impudence.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Or, Madam, he can leap over Three Joint-stools one upon another; you have them in the Room, Madam, you shall see that done presently.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Rogue, saucy Rogue, I'le cut your throat, wou'd you have me play the Tumbler?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Madam, have a care of the Old Gentleman, my Young Master is the finest Gentleman in the world, is desperately in love with, and must perish without you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Oh blessed news, but I must contain my self.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What say you to the Lady, you insolent Rascal.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Are you angry, Sir, that I speak a good word for you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Be not offended, Sir, nothing in the world cou'd have pleas'd me better than what he said to me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I am glad, Madam, any thing said in my behalf cou'd please you; your hand upon't, Madam, is it a match then?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You know in Spain our Wills are not our own, our Parents have 'em in keeping for us.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Why, Cousin, are you mad, will you marry shat Emblem of Mortality, that Death's head?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Thou little sprig of Envy, avoid, or I shall be furious.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Madam, you must go to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Is the Priest gone?

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Come on then, I'le venture.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: The vigour of my Love can bear no delay.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: There must be some time allow'd me in decency: But, Sir, since you begin to grow so particular, I must tell you a secret which concerns us both; have you not a Son nam'd Luscindo?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: What does she mean now?
