sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: A Son, Madam! I have a stripling, a tall boy, but he is very young, he is not above sixteen.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Madam, my Master mistakes, he is but fourteen.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I was married at thirteen, and had him before I was fourteen.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p:
Sir, you were married at eleven, did not I live (Bern bites his Thumb, and Makes signs to Hern.
with you? He was married before I was born:

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Curse on the Rogue. 'Tis true, Madam, but I had no Children till I was fourteen.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: 'Tis not for that I mention him, but if he be so Young, he is very forward, and I desire you will give a check to his ambition of serving me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! he dares not offer you his Love sure.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes, he has endeavour'd to corrupt my Maid, with this Heart of Ruby set in Gold: do you know it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No: but by the largest Whisker in Madrid, (Gad forgive me for swearing) it shall cost the owner the best blood in his body.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Be not rash, proceed with calmness: if some fool has taken his Name upon him, bid him, from me, endeavour to find the Owner, which will be no hard matter, that I may know who has injured me; and if it be he, advise him to leave no more Letters under a loose board in our Balcony.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Cannons and Culverins! have you a Letter of his?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No, I tore it in indignation.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Voto, I helpt to bring him into the world, and I'le send him out again.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir, Extremities will fill the Town with noise, and hurt my Honour: I conjure you, let a private Rebuke serve.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I'le obey, I kiss your hands; I'le find him instantly.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Fare thee well, thou art an Angel of thy Sex.

div.stage: Enter Tegue O Devilly, Gremia and Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p: Was ever such a Tyrant! you draw a stood of Tears from my poor Eyes, to see you use my Niece so savagely: Did ever woman write so passionate a Letter, did ever Lady so bewail her fault? With sobbing and tears, upon her knees, she ask'd your pardon.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Dou hasht a Rock inshtead of a heart indeed: I did maake a cry upon her phen I did she her, vid dee poor Laady.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: How are we all oblig'd to this good Man!

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Phaat dosht dou maake a graat laugh upon me, gra, arrah; I vill tell de now dou art very wicked, if dou dosht not taake pity upon de Laady, fait and trot.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Doristeo will pity her.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: I tell unto you, she dosh not caare for dat fellow; Joy, phaat vill I shay more? Hasht dou no Conshence, by my shoul?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Thou wert an excellent Pimp in Flander, I see thou hast not forgot thy faculty here.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: I do love to maake peash indeed between man and man, and man and voman; I do not know phaat dou dosht call Pimp, indeed.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p: O wicked wretch! wilt thou not hear the good man? So, here's the Rival, how we shall have fine work.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Peash voman, I will spaake to him, I musht be aafter shpaaking vid de gra; I vonder dou hasht no more Religion in dee, den to offer to taake anodder mans Mistress from him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A Pretty Habit, for a He-Baud.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Lay it upon dy Conshence; is not Levia Luscindo's Laady? phaat hasht dou to do vid her? De Casuists are clear in de point, it is a graat Shin, and a graat Faable.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am too nearly concern'd to have time for fooling, I am glad, Sir, I have met you.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Have you ought to command me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Ha, what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Having wounded my honour in so sensible a part, you must repair it by fighting with me.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: With your favour, Sir, you invaded my Right, but I have consider'd the matter, fighting is a solemn thing, and little Competitions about a Courtezan are not worth it.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Good Father, as you love Heaven, prevent their fighting.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, you have not carried your commerce with my sister so subtilly, that I am ignorant of it.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Your sister! upon my honour this is the first time I ever heard you had one.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am not to be trifled with, you know not Estiphania, the Widow, not her quality? you walkt not invisibly in the Prado, nor did you talk so softly, but your Discourses came to my Ear.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Is that it? ha, ha, what say you, Hernando?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Have you courage?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Ha, then 'tis no time to talk.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Now Father.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: No, I vill fly now; we Priests maake dee vorld fight, but we do not caare for it our shelves.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Guard your self.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: For Heavens sake hear me; is it true that the Lady Estiphania, whom Luscindo entertain'd in the Prado, was your sister?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why am I so concern'd else?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: I did not think my Mistress had been so well allied, her Mother fells fish, and she is little better than a Bulker.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Death and Hell, do you continue your mockery?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: By heaven 'tis true: I gave her a sounding Name, to put a trick upon Levia.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Oh Rascals, Villains, Poultrons! O Coward Doristeo, dare you not cut his throat? will you believe this lie?

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p: Hold, hold, ungracious Niece.

div.stage: (She flings Gremia down, who shrieks, and halts out.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Avaunt thou Bawd.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Oh my huckle-bone, my huckle-bone, ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir, you are a man of honour, and I must believe you; I ask your pardon for the trouble I have given you: pray give my friend and me leave to be your humble Servants.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be glad to serve you, and if that can do it, I give you all my interest in that Lady.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Ah Coward, I'le dispatch the Villain my self.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Finardo, help. (She snatches Doristeo's Sword, Sir, your humble Servant, I must endeavour to quiet this Lady, and runs at Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Let me go, Coward, Rascal; I hate thee of all mankind: Help, help, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: How cou'd you think on this creature?

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.p: I am reveng'd, and now I have done.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I have the best news for you, Elvira is infinitely in love with you.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: What say'st thou, dear Hernando?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Here's my Master, I must not be seen with you.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Now has he heard of my Visit to Levia, and is come with a dull wise Lesson.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: You stripling, I am come to tell you of a crime, which if you have the impudence to persist in, I'le make you the greatest Example of my fury that ever fell by this Arm.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Is it such a crime, Sir, for a Young Man in the heat of his blood, to love a handsome Wench?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Do you capitulate, Rascal? I'le make you know there is a difference of persons, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I hope I may pretend where others are freely admitted.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How others?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Yes, others; if you have better thoughts of her, you are much mistaken, I assure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Death, you Villain! dare you blast the honour of so innocent, so vertuous a Lady?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: She innocent and vertuous! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Peace, thou abominable Varlet, or I shall forget my blood, and pierce. hy heart.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Sir, are these terms fit for a Son?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Dogbolt, to blast the honour of my Mistress; by my beard thy Mother ne're was a chaster.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, Sir; if so, it wou'd be doubtful, whether I owe you that Respect I pay you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Audacious Coxcomb, her innocent freedom is above all malice, which join'd with her Wit and Beauty, has made her worthy of me, of Don Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: What a Devil will the old man commit incest?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I tell you, sirrah, she is your Mother-in-law, I am contracted to her.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: What do I hear! she my Mother-in-law! you will not prostitute the honour of our family, by marrying a Courtesan.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Abandon'd slave and lyar, she a Courtesan! Earthquakes, inundations, roaring Seas, and thunder! thou Puppy-dog, thou diest for't.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p:
Hold, hold, Sir, your Dagger,
Bern. draws his Dagger, drawn upon your son!

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Let me go, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you hold, there's some mistake.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Can any thing be so plain as thy blasphemy against Elvira? I will chastise thy black mouth'd insolence with Death.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Hell and Furies! is she contracted to him? then let his Dagger pierce my heart: but sure it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Abuse my Mistress Elvira! does your guilt alarm you?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: 'Twas Levia! I meant, what have I to do with Elvira?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: And what have I to do with Levia? shall that excuse?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: By heaven, Sir, I thought you had all this while spoken of Levia, the fine Courtesan, from whose house I now came: and do you think I ought not to be transported to hear you speak of marrying such a creature?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Jackanapes, you know not Elvira, you, you?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Not I: how, where, or when shou'd I know her? I can't guess your meaning.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You know not this neither, which you gave her Maid, to corrupt her to your interest.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Not I, I never saw it till now.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Know, Young Coxcomb, she has made another-guess choice, nor you left no Letters under a loose board in her Balcony?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I cou'd as well understand you if you spoke Arabick.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: She dispises you, bids you leave no more Letters: and if that Gem be not yours, she wou'd have you use all diligence to find the Owner, which will not be hard to do, that she may have satisfaction from him that has injur'd her: and I swear by all my former Atchievements, and magnanimous Deeds, I'le see her have it.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p:
Thou dearest creature upon Earth, I admire thy Wit as much as thy Beauty. (to himself.)
Be pleas'd to tell her, I will never rest till I see the owner, and that I resent this injury so, that I am resolv'd she shall have full satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Now you say somewhat: come prepare your self, I'le carry ye to see your Mother, and you shall ask her blessing.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: 'Tis in her power to give me the greatest in the world.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I'le carry you to her, because I'm resolv'd the day after to morrow you shall go to Flanders, while I settle here. Sirrah, Hernando, I have not reckon'd with you for your damn'd Lies, Rogue, but go now and tell Belliza we are coming to wait on her.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: I will, Sir,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Come stripling, follow me, I'le get some Pasteels, and stiffen my Whiskers, and so go.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I follow, Sir. (Ex. Bernardo. For Flanders! I'le see it under water, or, which is worse, all under the French King, e're I leave my Dear, my sweet Elvira?

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I hope, my Dear, thou hast not afflicted thy self for my absence: it seems to me an Age since I kiss'd this fair hand: Your Mother and I have seal'd and dispatch'd, and now thou'rt mine, my Dear, when shall a Domine do the Office? by my hilt and blade, I am all on fire for consummation.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No haste, I beseech you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: By my honour, but there is haste on my side, why, I am in a Fever, in a fiery Fever.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Some Musick, my Dear, I have provided for thee, though I must confess I delight in nothing but Haut-boys, Trumpets, Drums, Kettle-Drums, Whole Cannon, Demi-Cannon, Culverin, Half-Culverin, Musquet and Pistol, neighing of Horses, clattering of Arms, Groans of dying men, and such magnanimous military noises, fit for Hero's, yet I have provided softer Musick, befitting your soft sex: come in and sing a Love-Song, ye Scrapers, fit for the occasion

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sure this vapouring old Fool must be a coward.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: The Fire of Love in youthful blood,
Like what is kindled in brush-wood,
But for a moment burns,
Yet in that moment makes a mighty noise,
It crackles, and to vapour turns,
And soon it self destroys.
But when crept into aged Veins,
It slowly burns, and long remains,
And with a sullen heat,
Like fire in logs it glows, and warms 'em long,
And though the flame be not so great,
Yet is the heat as strong.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Love in aged Veins, you damn'd Fiddlers, you Scoundrels of Rosin and Catsgut, what have I to do with aged Veins, you Caterpillars, Vermine, most confounded Minstrils, I will crack your empty Noddles, and demolish your squeaking Fiddles, that you shall not be able to play before a Maypole.

div.stage: (He kicks and beats the Fiddlers out.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Methought they sung very well, what made you so passionate?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Uncivil Rogues, did I chuse them to entertain my Mistress, and must they Lampoon me with aged veins? aged, quoth they. But come, Madam, I'le entertain you with a heroick Song of my own, and I had provided this Drum to sing to, which is better than a Theorb, or Harpsycord.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Pray bless my Ears with it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I will, my Dear, strike up.

lg.l: The bullets are roaring, and Cannons are flying,
Wiih a thump, a thump, thump, thump, thump:
Cheer up my lads, ne're think of dying,
With a dump, a dump, dump, dump, dump.
Fall on my brisk boys of the blade,
With a dub, a dub, dub a dub.
Tara, tan, tan-tara, ra.
This is the Soldiers Tradc.

sp.p: Play the Ritomells. There's a Song, if you talk of a Song.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: 'Tis admirable.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I see, my dear, thou hast Judgment: Go on.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold, must my devout house be taken for a lewd Garrison? Thou creature of most military noise, be gone, must this wicked rattling be heard in my house?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: He shall go, but I take it ill you should call it, a wicked noise which the Hero loves above all pitiful effeminate Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Sir, your Son waits without.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Call him in: now my dear, thou shalt see thy Son-in-law, he is very young, and somewhat wild, he takes like his Father for that. He denies every thing thou dost tax him with, and knows nothing of the matter. (Enter Luscindo. Come Youth, come forward, and pay your Duty to your Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is this your Son, Noble Sir?

div.stage: [Bern. goes to present Luscindo to Elvira.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: It is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, I am your most obedient servant, and you are welcome, and ever shall be, under my Roof.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: You honour me exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He is a most excellent accomplish'd Person; oh heav'n! how my poor heart pants and throbs at him.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Is he not prodigiously tall of his age? Simple as he stands there, he is bare sixteen years old.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Madam, my Master speaks too modestly, he is but between fourteen and fifteen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good lack, I never saw the fellow of him.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Rogue, will you never take warning? Sirrah, get you out. Indeed, Madam, I thought he had been sixteen. [Ex. Hern. My dear, this is your Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I shall be proud of my Relation to him.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Let him do his Duty to you.

div.stage: [She pulls off her Glove, he kisses her hand and puts a Note into it.

sp.speaker: Luse.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis already a blessing to have kiss'd your fair hand, but I aspire at another benediction.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You shall not fail of all that I can give you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Fair hand, I like not that expression; his eager kiss, and his fix'd looks. Come, Madam, give him your blessing; I have appointed him his business, he must be gone.

div.stage: [He kneels down, she lays her hand on him.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Under a loose board, in our Balcony, you shall find an answer this Night. Heaven bless you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He is a sweet young Gentleman, I am enamour'd to the last degree, and methinks he looks amorously upon me.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Heaven let me contain my joys.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: His smooth Chin must be out of my way. Come, stripling, be gone, be gone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: No, no, be gone, be gone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ah, me! Elvira, is he gone? What will become of me, I shall faint?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I have appointed him to go towards Flanders the day after to morrow: He shall go where Honour calls him, while I stay here and sacrifice to Love.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O Daughter, help me to stop his Journy, or I am a lost Woman.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Is she caught already? Well, these melancholly devout Women, are the lovingest Worms upon occasion. Pray entertain my Lover, while I peruse a Note, wherein I have set down the things I must have before Marriage, and I'll endeavour to serve you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good Noble Sir, one word with you.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: With all my heart, a hundred if you please.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You seem too severe to this sweet young Gentleman your Son.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Not at all, Lady, he is a pert Boy, and w • ll be too forward if I use him otherwise.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: reads. Dear Madam, no passion ever equall'd mine, I adore your Beauty and your Wit, and am infinitely transported that you are pleas'd to let me know my happiness; but all this serves but to heighten my misery, unless your power, and your Mothers, can prevail with my Father to stop my Journy into Flanders, which he has resolved shall begin the day after to morrow.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Sir, one of your Flanders Officers has extraordinary business with you; he is at your House.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But why so soon for Flanders? methinks you should be pleas'd to have him in your sight, as I my self am.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I beseech you let him be present at my Wedding. [To him. I am sure he shall be so.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: When he has perform'd as many brave actions as I have done, he shall think of peace, but now Honour calls and he must go.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Does Honour call so soon?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, let me have interest enough to prevail with you for his stay till my Daughters Wedding.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: No, Madam, I have reasons to dispatch him away which I do not express.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And I have reasons to stay him here which I do not express.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: My dear good-by, afflict not thy self for my absence, I'le see thee again e're bed-time; I kiss thy hand. Farewell my beauteous Mother-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh I faint, I die, my dear Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Why Mother, Madam, Madam, this is a mighty Love-qualm: she recovers.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ah, my Luscindo.

div.stage: (Enter Tegue O Divelly, who stands by unseen.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: How, Madam, your Luscindo?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come, Daughter, 'tis in vain to endeavour to hide that Passion which has thus, in spight of me, betray'd it self: but 'tis wonderful to observe the power of Love, and sympathy, and all that, but to lose this sweet Young Man.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Trouble not your self, I'le bring all about yet; I spake even now of a Note, it was not what I told you, but a Ticket from Luscindo to me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To you! ah me, ah me! you are anoter mans wife, will you give ear to him?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Hold, Madam, mistake me not, he begs me to be his Advocate of Love to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ah, my dear child, to me, say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: He is infinitely taken with your person.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With me, that am wholly spiritual! but this sympathy of Lovers hearts is a great secret in Nature, • nough to puzzle all Philosophers. But where's the note?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I tore it, lest his Father should spy it, who is ignorant of all. Know, Madam, I am now your Mother-in-law by a double way, and will not bate an ace of my prerogative.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, dear child, thou art an arch one, I profess: well, go thy ways.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Take notice then, Daughter Belliza, you must be at your Balcony between Eleven and Twelve, and Luscindo will entertain you there, while I stand Centinel at the Wicket, and watch who comes by.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh blest news! I am transported. (aside.) You make me angry, Daughter: I entertain a man at midnight, when I should be at my Beads!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Come, Daughter, I will have my Title, and use my Authority: I advise, nay, command you as a Mother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, thou art a wag, I vow.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: There's no fear, I your Mother-in-law will take care of you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mother, then since thou wilt have it so, I give my self up wholly to your conduct.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Aboo, boo, boo, vilt dou sho joy, arrah, I vill put Excommunication upon dee, art dou not ashaam'd, and dosht dou not tremble to look me upon de faather, gra, didsht dou not maake Vow unto me, never to commit marriage, and like a pioush Vidow, to give dy estaate unto de Caatolick Church; Joy Trot, I vill maake dee know it is a mortal sin to maary, and I vill give dee up unto shaatan for dis gra.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Heaven, what shall I say! I am confounded.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Dou dosht behaave dy shelf gaallantly by my shoulwaation, how didsht dou dare to put dee out-side of the door upon me, hoh?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good Father hear me, I would marry to perswade my Husband to give his Estate to the Church.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Den dou voudsht be a pious Laady indeed, Joy, but he vill be aafter keeping dy Estaate and his own too an be.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: While he thinks to have power over my Estate, he is deceived; for I have by a private Deed put it out of his reach.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: It is very laudable and pious, if dou dosht cozen him to a holy and good end gra, but I will maake de groan under dy pennance indeed, for talking of deese fleshly matters upon a fish-day.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Ah, who is here?

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Ah, by my shoul have I cought dee again in my clutches, dou art possesht, I vill exorcise dee now.

sp.speaker: Rosan.
sp.p: Stand off, let me go, thou beast, thou Swine.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Dosht dou hear? dee fiend speaks in her body, and calls a Priest a Swine indeed. I vill conjure dee, phaat is dee Vidow gone? aboo, boo, she hash put dee out-side of de door upon me again: Daughter, awoyd dis plaash dat I may exorcish.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Help, help, Cousin, I vill tear his eyes out.

sp.speaker: Elvira
sp.p: Be gone, you lustful Villain, we will complain to the Fathers of the Inquisition.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: By my shoul I vill maake a great laugh upon dee, de inquisition is for de rich Jew, and de Heretick dog; come into another Chamber, Joy. Hold, hold, hold, dy wicked nails.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You a Priest! a Devil. Be gone.

div.stage: [They tear his Hood and Habit, and beat him out)

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Murder, murder, I vill excommunicaat, I vill excommunicaat.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Let's follow him, and see him out.

sp.speaker: Elvira.
sp.p: My mother threatens to send you to a Monastery to morrow.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: To a Monastery! I am for ever lost.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Let's retire, and consult how to prevent it; it grows very late, and it will be time to write, and lay my Note under the board in the Balcony. Rosania shall write it, that if my Mother should chance to find it, I may disown it: fear not, Rosania, I will contrive thy escape.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: A thousand blessings on thee.

div.stage: Levia, Gremia in the street, Levia in Mans Habit,

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Will you never go home? Though you care not for your Reputation, I will not lose mine.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Again thy stale advice, thy Reputation! thou art a Bawd, and a foolish one.

sp.speaker: Gre.
Lev.
sp.p: In short, good impertinent froward Aunt, either follow my directions, or we will part for ever.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: What shall I do if she leaves me? I am ruin'd. You know my good Nature too well, you will make me grey with sorrow.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Come, come, be a good towardly Aunt, and I'le pass by all; but do you hear, fail not of getting admittance to Belliza and Elvira, and tell them the story I have instructed you in.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You ever make a fool of me thus.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Too well I know now Elvira is the cursed Object of Luscindo's Love, and the cause of his deserting me.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p: I see you love him still.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I hate him beyond all aversion, and will be revenged though I perish with him: Where are my Rogues? Oh, are you come?

sp.speaker: 1 Bra.
sp.p: I never broke my word in my life, do you think I have no honour in me?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Fire this house, the Villain will then come out, and you may dispatch him.

sp.speaker: 1 Bra.
sp.p: We will dispatch him, but no firing of a house; that were to make a light to be caught by.

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p: O heaven, will you commit murder? I have contributed towards the making of many a man, and cannot in conscience consent to the destroying one.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Stir not, nor oppose me, if thou dost, by heaven I'le have thee kill'd.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Well, well, I'le say nothing, do what you will.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Here will I stand a statue at his door till he comes forth. Gentlemen, go ye and wait at the corner of the street, and when I whistle come. [Ex. Brav. Stand close, Aunt.

div.stage: Enter Elvira in the balcony, with a Ticket in her hand.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Go thou, dear Paper, and good luck atttend thee.

div.stage: (Which she lays under a board, then Exit.
Enter Luscindo and Hernando in the street.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Here comes company, I shall be discover'd before my time; let us retreat to our Main-Guard.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Place the Ladder here. (He goes up to the balcony, finds a Note.) Oh, here's the sweet Paper, away, dispatch, and hide the Ladder.

div.stage: [Hern. carries out the laadder, and re-enters immediately. Luscindo reads by his Dark-lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p:
What do I read! I am transported beyond my self. Reads.
Ioy of my Soul, The thoughts of our Separation are insupportable, which to prevent, I have perswaded my Mother, That you wrote, conjuring me by the Kindness of a Mother-in law, to propose you in Marriage to her, which took as I could wish, and she has, at my request, consented to entertain you at her balcony at midnight; fail not to be there with Hernando: She cannot know your voice; your statures are alike, and 'twill be too dark to distinguish Faces. If Hernando has Wit enough to act his part, and entertain my Mother, I shall have you free to my self at the Wicket, where we may provide for our happiness: And if my Art succeeds not, for your stay, assure your self, I will not stick at the boldest resolution you shall fix upon,
Yours intirely, ELVIRA.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Was there ever so charming a creature! Ah, dear Elvira, each minute is an age, till I have got thee within these arms. Time runs too fast for every other man, but for expecting Lovers is too slow, dear happy paper.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: We shall have you transported here, till your Father finds you.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Thou say'st right, let's in and bustle, as if we were putting up my Goods for Flanders.

div.stage: Enter Rosania in the balcony, and puts her Note under the board.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Go, thou dear Messenger of Love, and fall into the hands of him, who alone can deserve it.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: You need not go in, I'le bring you word if your Father be in bed.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Do so, Oh Elvira, let me kiss this Relique in absence of my Saint, my Joy is too great to bear.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Your Father is fast, he snores as loud as the Drone of a Bag pipe; an Alarm would not awaken him.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: To our business quickly, the Balcony-door opens, 'tis near midnight.

div.stage: Belliza and Elvira in the balcony.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Will Luscindo never come? I profess this is the longest night.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I hear some coming this way, it must be he and his trusty Hernando.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Lord, how my heart does heave and pant, my breath grows short, and every part of me is affected with the Passion.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Is my most divine and adorable Lady there?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Divine and adorable! I warant him a fine spoken man. [To her self. Hither your own, and your Mother-in-laws importunity has brought me, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: May I not have the liberty of entertaining you alone?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: (To Elv.) Go down to the Street-gate, and entertain Hernando at the Wicket, while Luscindo and I confer about our vertuous ends; and if any company comes by, give a hem.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: My dearest Saint of a Mother, who would not have trusted me with a Cat, now delivers me up, for her own ends, to a Young Man in the dark.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I shall never hold out without some Aqua Mirabilis, I grow so chill, and quake. Hold, I hear Rosania's Guittar; if she discovers me I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Thou Cordial of my Soul, art thou alone?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, but I hear some up in the house, I'le go and secure them, and wait on thee in a moment.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: (At the Wicket) My most incomparable Elvira, I know not which to admire most, thy Wit or Beauty, they are both so Angel like, thou dost so much transcend the rest of all thy Sex, that they appear but splendid trifles when compar'd to thee.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I know my self too well to apply this; all my hope is, that you have love enough to deceive your self; and since all happiness is but imagination, 'twill serve your turn as well as truth.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: 'Tis so real a blessing, and so great an honour, that to be King of Arragon, is a less title than the love of Elvira.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: This is the foolish dialect of lovers, which one who is not in love, would laugh at, and never think it were in earnest.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: By heaven, I am so much in earnest, that all the happiness you have rais'd me to, will prove my utmost torment, unless you take this opportunity to compleat it.

div.stage: (He offers to embrace and kiss her.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Stand off, mistaken young man, I confess my loose carriage has deserv'd this, but know Luscindo, that though my inclination was headstrong, that by indecent ways I sought to make my person and my passion known: Yet tho I have as much Love as ever woman had, I have as much Honour too, and the first minute of your attempt to lessen that, this poignard shall make the last of your life and mine.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: kneels. Dearest Elvira, by this I find but what I knew before, That your Vertue and Honour were equal to your Wit and Beauty. I beg a thousand pardons for my rash offer, but beg you will not too far mistake me; for when I once have so impious a thought as to attempt your honour, my poignard should do you Justice on me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, pray rise, this posture does not become you to me.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Should my love to you have the least mixture of dishonour in it, I should hate my self as much as I love you.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: May I believe you?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Upon the honour of a Cavalier, the compleating of the happiness which I desired, was our instant marriage; a man can no more love Elvira with dishonour, than he can love heaven, and be vitious; it were a contradiction.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Then my dear Luscindo, I ask thy pardon, here take this chaste Embrace, and with it heart and soul; I am thine, nor is it in the power of Fate to alter me.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Hold heart, my joys come now too thick upon me.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: But oh, Luscindo! I fear that all mine, and my Mothers Arts, will prove vain to procure a respite of your Journey.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Then I am lost, unless your Love be strong enough to carry you to the Noble resolution of—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What Resolution? Can you doubt my Courage?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: The resolution of making an escape, and flying to some distant place.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Your faith so plighted as it is, leaves no room for doubt, in such a heart as mine; I am resolved to run all fortunes with you.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: My Saint, my Angel, let me adore thee.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Come, come, talk like a Mortal, and consider of our escape.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: So, I have coun'd enough, and have all my piteous Love-sick language ready. Let me see, Suns, Moons, Stars, Planets, Lightning for Eyes: Roses, Cherries, Crimson, Scarlet, Tyrian Purple, for the Spanish Wool upon the Cheeks: Snow, Lillies, Milky way, for the Skin: Rubies and Coral for the Lips: And Gums, Pearls Oriental for the Teeth: Sun-beams and Golden Tresses for the Hair, that's sandy: Fire, Flames, Fry, Burn, Wounds, Pistols, Daggers, Halters, for my self; and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have secur'd all, and am return'd Noble Sir, and if you please you may proceed.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: My most venerably amiable, and amiably venerable Belliza, I am come to lay my heart before you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Most transcendently generous, and generously transcendent Luscindo, I must thank you for the passion which you bring.

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: A Pox on't, I do not know what to say to her. Let me see, I'll make Love in Rhime, out of Heroick Plays; 'tis even as natural here as upon the Stage.
sp.l: Dearest Ursa Major,
Which signifies a Bear.
I am so dazled with your radiant Eye,
That like the silly, and unheedful flye,
As sweetly the Heroick Poet sings;
At that bright flame I've sing'd m' advent'rous wings.
sp.p: Ha, that runs well enough.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Noble Lindamour, I find you are an errant Courtier; now you cannot see my lustre in the dark.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Can it be dark, dear Ursa, while those eyes
With such fierce beams my feeble sight surprize?
You shine so brightly that the vigilant Fowl,
Sacred among the Athenians, call'd the Owl,
Keeps in his silent Cloyster with the Batts,
And conscious of the light, the sullen Cats,
Forbear to Caterwaul, forget their passions,
And fail their sev'ral scratching assignations.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He has a bewitching Tongue, but comes not to the point.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Here's company coming; at Ten to morrow Night I'll not fail to have a Coach in the back-lane. Joy of my heart, farewel.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: My Life, my Soul, farewel: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good lack, she calls, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Hernando, here let us retire.

sp.speaker: Doristeo.
sp.p: My dearest friend, I am infinitely obliged to you for your assistance.

sp.speaker: Finar.
sp.p: Not at all, it is the duty of a friend.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Who are these? they go towards the Balcony: 'Sdeath! he is going up, I'le stop his proceedings.

div.stage: (Doristeo gets up on his mans shoulders, and takes the Note from the balcony.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Here's the dear Note, let me read. Reads,
Life of my Soul, my Mother threatens me with a Nunnery as soon as it is light, and except you come and rescue me, I am lost to you and all the world; for you are all I value in it.
Yours wholly, ELVIRA.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Let me draw, and see who this Traitor is, and punish his insolence. Ha, Doristeo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What lanthorn's that? let us retire.

div.stage: Enter Levia and Gremia, with Six Bravo's.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: This is the Villain, fall on.

div.stage: (They fight, Doristeo, Finardo and Sancho come in to Luscindo, they beat the Bravo's off.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: What Villains are these?

sp.speaker: Grem.
sp.p: Ah, ah, murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Ah, cowardly Dogs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hah, Luscindo, I am glad it was in my power to assist you against these Villains.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: (aside) Sir, I must confess I owe my life to you, let me see if I can fairly discover this Intrigue: What lucky accident brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You are a man of honour: I shall have need of your assistance: Elvira, the daughter of this devout Widow here, is my Mistress, and has left a letter, by appointment under a loose board in her Balcony, to let me know, that as soon as it is light, her mother intends to force her to a Nunnery, and conjures me to rescue her, I may have of so gallant a mans Sword, which I know you will not deny me; there's the Note.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Oh heaven and earth, it is her hand, the same with my Note! O Devil can so much beauty have so much falshood? Draw, and defend your self; you saved my life, but have now forfeited your own: this Elvira is my mistress, whom if you resign not to me, you must die.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You mistress! resign or die! Nay, then have at you. Sancho, stir one step, and I will cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Take your life, I now am even with you.

div.stage: (Luscindo and Doristeo fight, and Finardo and Hernando: Luscindo and Hernando disarm the other two.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Accursed fortune!

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Take your Sword, and say you are beholding to me.

div.stage: Enter Bernardo in his Night-Gown, with Servants and Flambeaux, and Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: What clashing of Swords and fighting has been here?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Let us retire from these lights.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Ungracious boy, is't you? whom have you fought with? what had you to do here? I'le pack you away for Flanders.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I must confess I was somewhat late taking leave of my Mistress, and as I was coming home, I found a Gentleman, and Two with him, he climb'd the Balcony, and I not knowing but it might be to violate the honour of your Mistress, Hernando and I fell upon them, disarm'd them, and gave them their lives at present.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Voto, Voto, Diabolo, why did you give them their lives? let's follow, and murther them.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: They are fled out of distance, but I know the Gentleman, whom I will go to in the morning, and make him promise under his hand to make no more attempts, or I'le cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Damnation, you foolish boy, why did you give him his life? Shall any Villain live who attempts the honour of Don Bernardo's Mistress?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I gave him his life, because I ought mine to him; for just before, I was set upon by half a dozen Bravo's, and he fought gallantly, and relieved me.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: How Bravo's! what a Devil's this?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Let's in, Sir, and we'll consult what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Come on, I am in a mist, I know not what to think on't.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: IF ever life or liberty were dear to thee; if ever love enter'd thy tender breast, and thy Luscindo has possession there, pity my sad condition. Must I be buried while alive with Melancholy and Green-sick •• s'd Nuns? your pious hypocrites and Chalk-eaters, and lose for ever my dear Doristeo? Upon my knees I beg thy help; if ever thou hadst compassion in thee, show it now.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I will, my dear Rosania, fear not, I will prevent thy going to this dreadful Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: There is but one way left: thou art intrusted by my Aunt with the keys of the house, I have appointed Dcristeo to be ready this morning, let me out, and I shall owe my life, my love, and all the world to thee.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I am intrusted, and would'st thou have me false to that trust?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: 'Tis to be true to love, the greatest power upon earth, oh, be not false to that.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I must consult my conscience.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Oh, look not, dear Elvira, to succeed in any of thy wishes, if thou desertest me now.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I will not quit thy interest.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: There is no way left but this, which if thou should'st deny me, I am for ever miserable.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: How knowest thou Doristeo is not wicked, and may violate thy honour?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: I know first, that I will part with my life before I yield my honour; besides, he has the reputation of a gallant man.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Well, I will strain a point for thee, and let thee out, and I wish thee all the happiness fond lovers can imagine.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
Elv.
sp.p: Adieu, my dear Rosania, (Elvira unlocks the Wicket, aud lets Rosania out. thou art very near thy happiness; I would I had as little difficulty; but let it be never so great, I am resolved to surmount all, for my dear Luscindo's fake.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What do you up so soon?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: My concern for you, daughter, would not let me rest: I came out of my Chamber, thinking I had heard the door open; did not you hear something?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes: which made me come out of my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: We were deceived, the door's shut, and I have the keys in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, this Luscindo is a charming person, he so bewitch'd me with his Tongue, my Eyes have never come together, dear daughter.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Again, daughter!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Dear Mother then, take care of me, or I am lost in the flower of my age. Hah, what knocking's that?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I know not: If some body has caught Rosania, and brought her back, both she and I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Madam, yonder's the Irish Father with a grave Old Gentlewoman at the door, desire Entrance; your Ladyship has the Keys.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Here they are.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I know not.

div.stage: Enter Tegue O Divelly and Gremia.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Good morning Daughters, the Saints bless ye; here is a good pious antient and reverend Laady that vould be after spaakeing vid dy Faaders child and dine own der gra arrah: She is a Gaallant Laady, and Lovet de Church, and is very dewout indeed, a Laady of great rank, and wertue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Would your Ladyship have ought with me?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Are you Donna Belliza?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Your Ladyships most obedient Servant: and is this your Daughter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is▪

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I am your Ladyships most humble servant to command.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Do you not she now she is a graat Laady of great solidity, of much breeding, good behaviours, and formalities and be?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You are then the mother, and she the daughter; good, I have somewhat to impart to both your Ladyships, which concerns me and both of ye.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: She is a fine-spoken Laady as any in Madrid, no dispraise, I tell you Joy.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: There is nothing so dear, so precious in the world to a Lady as her Honour and Reputation; very well; and my concern for this is the occasion of my waiting upon you now: do you conceive me?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Not I, Madam, truly.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Go to: I have a Niece whom I have educated from her first budding, till she is become mature, as I may so say, and ripe for gathering, good.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She has a fine tongue truly.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Did I not shay sho to dee gra?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: In this Niece did I place all my Joy, having brought her up to all the rules of strictest Vertue? right; do you understand me? Now this Niece, de conceive me, is one of the g • eatest beauties in Madrid; de see? well.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What is her Name?

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Ab • o, by my shoul she is aafter telling a great lye indeed.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Now there is a Neighbour of your Ladyships, one Don Bernardo, and he has a Son named Luscindo, very good, as fine a person as the Sun e're shined on, a person, de understand me? but to go on.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Whither does her discourse tend? pray heaven he be not inconstant.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Now this Luscindo is a man of shining honour, by his Deeds in Arms, de conceive me now? what does me this Luscindo, I say, what does me he do?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What does this impertinent creature drive at?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I say, what does me he but prune himself, and strut before her window with amorous contenance and mien? very well: dogs her when she goes to Church, whispers in her ear at Mass; de see; Serenades her every night: good now, what does me she.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: She has a raare shilver tongue, fait, an be, she dosh talk gaallantly by my shoulwaation:

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I say, what does me she, alas, good Ladies, you cannot but conceive, that we of the frail Sex are liable, and so forth, de understand me? Good, my Neice, my poor frail Niece; alack, alack! I cannot speak for tears.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My mind misgives me; I am miserable; I scarce dare stay to hear the fatal Story.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I say, what does me my Niece but become amorous of this young charming person? well, gives him a meeting, signs a contract as he to her, and since he has left her for this young Lady, and has the impudence to own his new Passion. My poor Niece lies distracted, tearing of her hair, bound in her bed.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Elv
sp.p: Oh, savage Monster, I'le not bear this vile affront; she tells it so naturally it cannot be feigned.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: I vill maake testification upon Oat, dat all dis is true and shartain, fait and trot gra.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ah, ah, Luscindo, Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Ah me, help, help my Lady, cut her Lace, cut her Lace, get some Arsa foetida, blew Inkle, or Patridge Feathers, and burn under her Nose. I hope I did not occasion this.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: By my shoul I vill fling shome holy vater in her faash, and cross it, and it vill maake cure upon her. (He pulls out a bottle of Holy Water, and sprinkles some upon Belliza's face, and crosses, and mutters. Dey call defe fits, but by my shoul dey are de evil Spirits dat vill get in at de mout, if vee do not ta • ke great caare of dem.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh, vile Luscindo! but heaven has justly punish'd me for leaving my Beads for the vanity of Love: Oh, holy Father, 'tis you must give me comfort, I wholly resign my self into your hands, and will ever give my heart to heavenly matters, and retiring from the world.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Retire, Madam, into your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will, follow me holy man.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I am sorry to find I am the cause of so much disturbance in this good family, but I thought I was as well concern'd for the Love to my Niece, as in honour to you, to let you know of Luscindo's contract; and so I kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Farewel Madam. (Ex. Gremia. O vile Luscindo, thinkest thou that I can be content with a false title to thee, with a heart that's mortgaged to another? I will revenge this base indignity by instant marriage with thy Father this morning: Oh, false, false Luscindo!

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Why, Diego, Sirrah, Drone, Bear, Dormouse, stir, Rogue; by my beard I think an Earthquake would not wake thee: why sirrah, are you in a dead sleep?

div.stage: Enter in his Morning-Gown, and Diego to him.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I was, Sir, till you were pleas'd to call me to life, but to a wearisome one, if you will not suffer me to take out my sleep.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Thou would'st out-sleep the seven sleepers: 'tis broad day.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: I see that as well as you, Sir, and better too; for my eyes are younger.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Lazy Rascal, the Rising-Sun upbraids thy sloth.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: I am sure he went to bed before me.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: But sirrah, leave your prating, and tell me, did I not hear the Wicket open?

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: How can I tell whether you heard it? you can resolve your self much better of that than I.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Peace, thou son of a Strumpet, what have you a mind to be witty? I am confident I heard it: this lewd boy of mine has been abroad all night; I shall never rest till he be in Flanders: Sirrah, go see if my Son be in his chamber, and bring me word.

sp.speaker: Luscin.
sp.p: Tell my Father we have been packing up my Goods for Flanders.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Is't possible Elvira should be false? How can it yet be otherwise? this Note to Doristeo is too plain a proof to leave me any room for doubt; Was e're misfortune yet like mine.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: There must be some mistake, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Sir, there is a Letter for you from my Young Lady.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: Gry.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Hernando, which is Don Bernardo's apartment?

sp.speaker: Hern.
sp.p: Go in there.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p:
Hah, this is another, hand.
He reads,
You may spare your self and friends the pains of coming to carry me away, your falshood and unworthiness shall be revenged by my instant marriage with your father, nor will I ever see you more in any other quality than that of your Stepmother,
Elvira.

Ha, what means she by my falshood? This may be her mothers hand, they are afraid this dishonourable falshood with Doristeo should take air, and her mother would marry her instantly to my Father: I will go to her, and do whatever jealousie and fury may prompt me to.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ho there, call all my Servants, bid 'em be ready for my Wedding, which is to be out of hand this morning. Oh my sweet Elvira. Now Youth, Stripling, now you shall see my Wedding, and let the Young Coxcomb break his heart: what care I? (aside) bid all my Servants come in to me, and sirrah, Diego, bid my Apothecary come, I will have a strengthening Cordial to enable me to carry my self like a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: What good will that do? she will soon find you out.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Gad take me, if I pay down a lusty Fine, she shall be content to bate of her Rent. De hear? let me have Musick, and do you get me good Kettle-Drums and Trumpets, I will have pomp as well as dispatch: Away, let all the rest of my Servants come to me.

div.stage: Gremia and Levia in the Street, Elvira in the Balcony, veil'd, and standing close.

sp.speaker: Elv.
Lev.
sp.p: I am extreamly pleas'd that your story caused such distraction in the family; Now you are a good Aunt.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Ay, too good for you, how can I be rewarded?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Here he is: can there be falshood in that charming person?

sp.speaker: Levia.
sp.p: Here comes the Villain: Stop, Hell-hound, stop.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Oh heaven, what now will her madness prompt her to?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Now look me in the face.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Take it away, I like it not.

sp.speaker: Levia.
sp.p: Audacious wretch, take that.

div.stage: (She gives him a box on the ear, Gremia steps between.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: A fair Ladies hand can give no affront.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: What, a Coward too! nay, then all must be true I have heard of him; I'le see no more, I am distracted: would I had seen a Basilisk when I saw thee.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: If you give not over, I will expose you to the last degree of infamy.

sp.speaker: Levia.
sp.p: Poor fool, I'le have thy Life, or make Madrid too hot for thee.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Whither will my despair hurry me? Now to my cruel and my false Elvira.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
Unhappy creature, to what miseries have my too fatal eyes betray'd me?
Had I never beheld this false Luscindo, I had rested, and undisturb'd, enjoy'd my quiet sleeps, and all the wonted calmness of my Soul; but Love, vile Love, disorder'd all my frame, and had no sooner taken possession here, but I must turn him out again. But, Oh! What sharp convulsions must I suffer, e're I dispossess this most distracting inmate? Oh Heaven! What's this!

div.stage: Enter Luscindo with his Dagger drawn.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, fear not me, I can commit no violence on you: This is to execute whom you condemn: Your cruel Falshood and your Tyranny, might do it soon without the help of this.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: My Falshood, vilest of men, how dare you accuse me of a black Crime which I detest and scorn, as much as I should thee, who art so evidently false, that thou hast forced me in a just resentment, to execute my self, and bury all my Youth in thy loath'd Fathers arms for my revenge.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I false! witness ye Saints in heaven, how I am injur'd: Had a blest Angel said this, I would have pronounced it a false and evil Spirit; but Doristeo has confess'd your falshood, show'd me your Ticket, at which I fought with him, and being sever'd in the streets, I kept your Billet to upbraid your falshood with, which here behold. And I suppose you have found this Doristeo false! and fling your self upon my Father.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Doristeo, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lus.
sp.p: Am I become your scorn, as well as your aversion? then 'tis time to fall.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You do not, Sir, from me, deserve a serious answer, that bring a heart. already vow'd to another, Henrietta de Sylvia: you find you are discover'd. I am to blame in holding this long commerce with so perfidious a man as you.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: By heaven, and all the powers above, I never once heard of her Name till now; but you can write, and make a sacrifice of me, the most passionate and faithful Lover your Beauty e're shall gain, to Doristeo.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Though you deserve not any satisfaction, in vindication of my honour yet I do avow 'tis not my hand.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Nor this?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Nor that.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: 'Tis well you had your Confident to write, that whensoe're you pleas'd, you might disown it: Falshood to the height, then this is yours.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: It is, and you deserve it from me; and I resent your injury so much, I have condemned my self to misery, perpetual misery, for my revenge. Ah! think then how I could have loved.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Could you? By Heaven, and all its Powers, I am not false, nor ever heard the Name you mention'd.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Did you not even now, part with her Aunt, and a young Gentleman, who I suppose is of her kindred? But what can I expect from one so mean, as could receive a blow?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Oh Heaven and Earth! I am the vilest Wretch, the basest Miscreant, if that young Gentleman be not one Levia, a famous Courtezan! The other Person is a Baud, her Aunt. This Courtezan unfortunately cast her love on me, and has for my neglect, and scorn of her, pursued my life.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Father Tegue introduced her Aunt to my Mother and me, and vouch'd her for a Lady of Quality, and all she said for truth.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Did you once know the vileness of that Priest, you would as soon believe the Devil.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I know he is a Villain. [aside. His story looks like truth; indeed, I cannot on second thoughts believe that he could take a blow from any man. I fear I've been too rash, and am undone. To my own honour this is due; the last Nights Note, to you, was written by my Cousin Rosania, if my Mother found it I might disown it to her. That to Doristeo, was from, and for her self; he fell in love with her, took her for the Daughter, me for the Niece; and Rosania has carried on her correspondence with him in my Name; and this the Powers of Heaven can witness is all true.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: O Heaven, what fatal accidents have hurried me even to the brink of Ruine? Low on the earth, and at your feet I will for ever lye, till you shall pardon me my base suspicion that you were false, and will believe me true.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Rise, Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Then am I happier than all the prosperous Monarchs of the Earth: I was plung'd into the lowest Gulf of Darkness, and now am raised to visit Light again.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Hold, not too fast, I see no prospect yet of a clear light, but Clouds and Storms about us. Our most unfortunate mistakes, have carried me so far to make the engagement to your Father, and I can see no way to break it.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: How, Elvira! Those fatal Words contain my sentence, since you can be so unkind as now to think of quitting me, to make my Father happy,
sp.l: And give that Heart to him engaged to me,
This fatal Instrument shall set you free.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Hold dear, and more than ever dear Luscindo, I am intirely yours; nor Fate, nor Time, nor Death, shall fever us.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Let me for ever hold you within these Arms, and let our Love, like to a broken Limb, grow stronger.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: We have no time for Raptures, no escape can now be made; the Streets are full, and we shall soon be forced from one another.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: It remains that we must do what cannot be undone, and find a Priest to join us instantly.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Here's one at hand, I must confess, a wicked one.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Most opportunely come, I'll make him him do it. Father, let us withdraw, we have some business to consult your wisdom in.

sp.speaker: Teg.
sp.p: Come den, I vill do phat I can for your Fauders Child, joy; and I vil employ all my visdom upon you gra.

div.stage: Bernardo in his House, with his Servants in the Barbers hands.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Are all my servants ready, to wait in their best accountrements?

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: They are without, Sir, and Hernando is gone for a Priest, and Musick, and Kettle-Drums.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p:
This is a joyful day, and I will celebrate it with all the pomp I can: come Washball, refresh my countenance, and take off the superfluous crop; but
as thou lovest thy Ears, or Nose, that bolt-sprit of thy face, prophane not my inviolate Whiskers: for every single hair thou shalt diminish there, I will lop off from thee a member, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, I know the value of a Whisker in Madrid.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p:
Come, Snip, Snap, begin. (He puts his Cap and Cloath on.
Enter Levia. How now, Springall, who art thou?

sp.speaker: Levia.
sp.p: Pardon, Sir, my abrupt intrusion. I doubt not but you are so much a Cavalier as to protect a Gentleman in distress.

sp.speaker: Bern.
Lev.
sp.p: I am happy to fall into the hands of such a gallant man.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Thy story, Lad, thy story: thou art as safe here as in the Castle of Millain.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I'le tell it, Sir, in whisper and in short.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Stand back all.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I have been several times of late dog'd and assaulted by Bravo's, and by the confession of one of 'em, whom I took, I found that they were hired by a Young Lady of your Neighbourhood, Elvira, daughter to Donna Belliza.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: How say'st thou, stripling?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: And which makes me apply my self to you, they say your Son Luscindo joyns with her in the bloody business; and except you can take him off, and get him to prevail on her, one time or other I must fall a sacrifice to their fury.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Diabolo, Elvira and my Son!

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: By heaven 'tis true, the fellow is here ready to testifie it; but did you know me, my honour would pass with you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: But hold stripling, why should they pursue your life?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: You are a man of honour, and have promised me protection, and I'le hide nothing from you; the truth is Elvira is my Mistress, I have enjoy'd her, and she has sacrificed me to Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hell and damnation.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Her barbarous usage, and your generosity, will clear my honour for revealing this, they thinking that they cannot enjoy themselves in freedom while I live, endeavour to dispatch me, and but last night.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Last night! Furies and Devils, this must be true, I thought he had not known her.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: I saw him this morning sneak into the house; she let him in, and there he was even when I enter'd here.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Where's my Sword? Come Youth, by Belzebub and all his host of Devils, thou shalt see 'em both fall by this arm, come along.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Shall I take my Clothes off.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Damn thee Nit.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: Will you not put on your clothes, Sir, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I'le cut thy throat, Dog, follow me all,

div.stage: Belliza, Elvira, Tegue O Divelly in Belliza's House.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh this good man has fix'd my wandring mind,
And set it all on Heaven, and things above:
How had I given the reins to Vanity,
That I should suffer Love to enter here,
And justle out devotion? Holy Father,
I am resolv'd to expiate my crime,
The remnant of my life within a Cloyster:
Ah, what a • ound comfort shall I find?
sp.p: Daughter, I am glad that thou art resolv'd so soon to marry; and I will leave my House to thee.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
Elv.
sp.p: A brace of Hypocrites well met, Is this wicked woman here?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Oh, Ladies, upon my knees I humbly beg your pardon, I apprehend the mischief I have caused; I was wrought upon by my wicked Neice to tell you a story, every word of which was false; Luscindo is unblemish'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How! is Luscindo true?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes sure, but you are resolved for a Monastery.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who tells you so? that was on supposition of his falshood. Luscindo true, then I am happy.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Did not you say, all was true?

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: 'T was for a pious end dat I speake it.

sp.speaker: Grycia.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I am undone, ruin'd, Mrs. Rosania is fled, gone out of the house, and no where to be found.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh heaven, I am undone, I should have sent her this day to a Monastery. Ah, who is here?

div.stage: Enter Bernardo, Levia, Hernando, and Servants holding him, his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Let me go, Dogs, Rogues, Villains, Caterpillars.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Call my men-servants to help to hold him.

div.stage: [Grycia goes out, and Men enter with her, who lay hold on Bern.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Where is this Strumpet Elvira, and this Son of a Whore Luscindo? They shall both fall a sacrifice to my fury. Let me go.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold him fast, he is distracted.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: He is possesht, let me alone vid him, Joy.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Are you there, foul creature?

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Benedicite, dere is shome Holy Vater in de fash of dee. (He flings Holy Water in his face. Conjuro te demonem Belzebub Satanam per
Caesare camestres festino Baraco darapti
Felapton Disamis Datisi Bocardo Farison.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Let me go, dogs, and first I will exorcize you, Rascal.

div.stage: (He beatt the Priest, knocks him down, and stamps on him, who all the time roars out the Exorcism. They lay hold on Bern, the Priest gets up, and goes on in exorcizing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O heaven, he is possess'd, and has committed Sacriledge upon the good man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh my dear Luscindo, art thou here?

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what is the matter? unhand my Father.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Ungracious Rascal, have at thy heart, Let me go. Oh Villain, had you and that Strumpet Elvira, none to put your vile affronts on, but on me? Must I marry your Wench, and one that was a Whore to another before?

div.stage: [He runs at him with his Dagger. Hernando stops him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh save my dear Luscindo.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: If any man but my Father said this, it should be his death.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: How now, Ruffian!

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Let me come, he is possesht I tell dee, Exorcizo te.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Stand by, Fool.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Fool! I tink dou art possesht too, Joy, and I must exorcise dee, to call a Priest Fool, and be, aboo, boo, boo.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: There's a Young Gentleman can tell, and you, base wretches, pursue his Life for't.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: 'Tis all true.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Hold, let me speak; If you presume that I am such a creature, you freely will resign me.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Resign thee to the Devil; but think not I'le sit down with this Affront; I'le be patient for a moment,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is all false, the ancient Gentlewoman has confest it, and my Luscindo, my dear Luscindo's true. Oh vile Girl, art thou there?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I am return'd, but with another Guardian, my Doristeo.

sp.speaker: Dorist
sp.p: I am come to wait upon you with my Wife; and since your denial cannot undo what is already done, I beg your consent.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le never give it while I live.

sp.speaker: Levia.
sp.p: Hell and Furies, have I lost him too!

sp.speaker: Dorist.
sp.p: Pardon me, dear Luscindo, for my mistakes, and impute them to our evil fortune. You are a man of honour, and I beg your friendship.

sp.speaker: Luscind.
sp.p: You have shown your self a Gentleman, and I shall take it for an honour to be call'd your friend.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: I'le slit your Wind-pipe, and spoil your complements, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Your fatal using of my Name, has caused such mischievous mistakes, as did go near to ruine me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now, dear Luscindo, we are free.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Since you are pleas'd to resign me, my Husband Luscindo, will own me with all my Faults.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ah me, ah me! Father stand by me.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Own thee, yes, while I have life and motion, as my greatest happiness. Were this a man, I'd send his soul into another world, but 'tis a woman, a malicious one, and a Whore.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Heavens curses on ye all, here take my Life, and I shall thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Keep it to be a torment to thee.

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.p: Most violent Love, and invincible impotence, possess thee, and continual rage and jealousie her; and so with curses on ye all, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Devil, what has my rashness brought me to? I could kill the dog; but let me think on some firm and lasting vengeance. I have it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Father, I wholly now give my self up to a Cloister'd Life.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Daat is my good daughter.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: If you can forgive your poor Soldier, Bernardo, who finds that you alone are worthy of him, I return to my first Love, and am ready, dear Widow, to consummate, without more delay.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What says he? are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Out, phat dosht dou do now? dou vilt not hearken to the tempter gra▪

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Lady, I seldom kneel, Lady, but in this posture humbly beg you to receive me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To show I am in charity with all the world, and can forgive, I receive you as my husband.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: A thousand blessings on thee, my dear Widow, Sirrah, Young Rogue, I will get every year a child these twenty years, and make thy heart ake.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: I wish you Joy, Sir,

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Much Joy, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go, perfidious wretch, thee I will ne're forgive.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I do forbid the Baanes: dou vert espous'd unto the Church first, and that does dirimere contractum, & irritum reddere sponsalia.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Well said Priest, with false Latin.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Sirrah, Priest, if you do forbid the Banes, I will cut your throat. Do you hear? You that were my unlawful Pimp, and joyn'd me to many Whores in Flanders, shall be my lawful Pimp, and joyn me to one Wife in Madrid, or by Heaven I will exorcise you with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Tegue.
sp.p: Vel, vel, shay no more Joy, I vill do phat dou spakest. By my shoul I will pronounce the words of de maarriage without intention, and den it is no maarriage, and all deir posterity vill be aafter being Bashtards, as all de School men say; and by my shoulwaation dere is a trick for dem.

sp.speaker: Lusc.
sp.p: Now dear Elvira, may our mutual Love shine clear, without one cloud upon it. Heaven let me but possess my dear Elvira,
sp.l: And I renounce all earthly joys beside.
Thus Fortune kindly does for Love provide.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: MEthinks I hear some Ladies nicely wise,
(I do not mean the vertuous, but precise)
Cry down us Spanish ones, and call us light,
Who entertain our Lovers at first sight.
But Ladies think, were you like us confin'd,
Alas! you'd soon be of another mind.
You at the first fair game before you eye,
As fiercely as unhooded Hawks would fly.
Though Nature largely does for us provide,
Yet all its beauteous store, we're forc'd to hide,
Which but by dangerous stealths is never spy'd.
You can your Faces every where expose,
And throw your piercing Darts against the Beaux:
But we are wiser yet than you; for we
Ne're wait a second opportunity.
You shall for Months your amourous glances cast,
And bring it but to Scandal at the last.
We never spread our loving Nets in vain,
We soon come to a point, and ease the pain:
Your Beauties you so oft in publick show,
That Gallants of your Faces weary grow.
So that before you're known, you are enjoy'd,
And Sparks, before they come to taste, are cloy'd.
To feed their Pride, not Love, some have a train
Of flutt'ring Slaves, to grace their stately Reign;
Their sickly appetites are so diseas'd,
They make men jealous, and themselves not pleas'd.
We're seldom seen, and but by those we like,
And when the Iron's hot, ne're fail to strike.
But though we're wiser, you are happier still,
As if we had no Souls, we have no Will:
For our Tyrannick Countrey thinks it fit,
To Kindred or to Husbands we submit.
Whene're we are discover'd by ill chance,
A life is forfeit for a single glance.
Your Sisters or your Daughters safely stray,
And with a Groom or Parson run away:
On this affront the Kinsmen never think,
But as they use to do, hunt on and drink.
For every Favour a poor Spanish wife
Bestows on her Gallant, she ventures life.
The wanton English ones need never fear,
By their good men they're ever held most dear,
And none such hands over their Husbands bear:
The Husband none so closely does embrace
As the sweet Gallant who supplies his place.
VVell—
Though on the Stage we Spanish women be,
Elsewhere we can use English Liberty.
Now for the Poet, I ha' nought to say,
Has cast himself upon you, and ye may
Do what ye please, or save, or damn his Play.
